loans.use: Purchase of shoes

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
44 year-old Jocelyn J. lives in the village of Brgy Batang, Himamaylan City, Negros Occidental. Her husband, Larry, is a fisherman and they are blessed with 4 children who are between 18 and 24 years old. Her dream is for her children to earn their college degrees and get a good job, so that they can enjoy a comfortable life.

To help her husband achieve this dream, she sold her husband's daily fish catch either within their community or in the nearby villages. Her hard work and perseverance bore fruit so that she needed new capital just to maintain her sales volume. This inspired her to join NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1991 so that she could continuously access new capital for her business.

With new capital, she was able to expand the product lines in her general store; her business activities have been a big help in supporting all of the needs of their family, slowly improving their living conditions. As her business improved, she also engaged in food vending, which she put up in front of her general store. Now she earns about PHP 19,200 per month, which she adds to her revolving working capital and she saves most of her income for the education of her children.

Her previous loan of PHP 29,500 contributed a lot in developing her business and even her performance in NWTF-PD, maintaining her good credit record. The said amount was fully paid on-time without any delay. As Center Chief, her good credit performance makes her a good example to her members. Now in her 19th cycle, she is borrowing the same amount of PHP 19,500 to be used to obtain additional capital for her general store and for the repair of her pumpboat.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To obtain additional working capital for her general store.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita F. is 46 years old and their 7 children are between 13 to 25 years old, 6 of whom are still attending school. They live in the village of Batang Himamaylan City Negros Occidental. Her husband Ricardo helps her in running the business. She dreams that her children will finish in college and have a stable job, to help her husband improved their living and to look for an opportunity where she can develop her business and earn an income for a living.

Teresita's business is to sell different kind of ready to wear items like clothes, pants, hats, sacks and many more. They need to wake up early in the morning to go in different places where there is a market day. But she noticed that she need additional stocks to compete other traders. Her problem is that she lack capital.

In the year 2000, she joins NWTF-Project Dungganon to find additional capital for her ambulant business. Her stocks increased and her income also increased, aside from this she also put up her general store adjacent to her house. Her businesses are a big help to her family especially for the education of her children. As her loan increases her opportunity to invest in other business was high, so she expanded business into Food Vending and puts the finished product in her general store. Now she earns Php 15,000 per month and she save most of her income for the education and family expenses.

Her previous loan of Php 26,000 was use as additional capital for her business especially in ambulant vending. She maintain her good credit performance by paying her loan on time and in full without delayed. Teresita borrows her 13th cycle loan with the same amount of Php 26,000 to be use as additional working capital for her general store.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital for her general store

loans.name: Celia

texts.es:
La socia CELIA  es una humilde madre de familia que pertenece al banco comunal “VIRGEN PURIFICADA - ANGOSTURA”.    

La socia tiene 30 años de edad es madre y padre para sus dos hijas. La hija mayor estudia en el colegio y la hija menor estudia en el jardín. Nuestra socia vive en el distrito de San Jerónimo en la comunidad de Angostura que se encuentra ubicada al sur de la ciudad del Cusco. La socia se dedica a la venta granos como cebada, trigo y maíz en el mercado “Vino Canchon” en el distrito de San Jerónimo Ya son varios años que trabaja en el negocio y le ha ido muy bien gracias a todo el empeño que pone en su trabajo. Nuestra socia es una madre trabajadora y emprendedora que va sacar adelante a su familia. La socia requiere el préstamo para comprar más menestras para luego vender. Ella dice ser una madre que no le teme a las adversidades y que seguirá luchando para ser feliz y sacar profesionales a sus dos hijas. 

La socia se encuentra agradecido por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Celia is a humble mother who belongs to the “VIRGEN PURIFICADA - ANGOSTURA” [Purified Virgin - Angostura] Communal Bank. She is 30 years old and serves as both mother and father to her two daughters. The older daughter goes to grade school, and the younger one is in nursery school. Celia lives in the San Jerónimo district in the community of Angostura, which is located in the southern part of the city of Cusco. She works selling grains such as barley, wheat and corn at the “Vino Canchon” market in the San Jerónimo district. She has been working in this field for several years, and it has gone very well for her, thanks to all of the dedication she puts into her work. She is a hard-working and entrepreneurial mother who will continue to make progress for her family. She needs this loan to purchase more grains and dry beans to sell. She reports that she is a mother who is not afraid of adversity, and that she will keep striving to be happy and to raise her two daughters to become professionals. Celia is appreciative of the opportunity provided to her in this manner, and she is committed to making all of her payments according to schedule.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing more grains and dry beans to sell

loans.name: Melchora

texts.es:
La socia MELCHORA es una humilD. madre D. familia que pertenece al banco comunal “VIRGEN PURIFICADA - ANGOSTURA”.    

La socia tiene 70 años D. edad, es viuda y tiene cuatro hijos. Los hijos ya trabajan y son independientes. Nuestra socia vive en el distrito D. San Jerónimo en la comunidad D. Angostura que se encuentra ubicada al sur D. la ciudad del Cusco. La socia se dedica a la venta granos como cebada, trigo y maíz en el mercado “Vino Canchon” en el distrito D. San Jerónimo Ya son varios años que trabaja en el negocio y le ha ido muy bien gracias a todo el empeño que pone en su trabajo. Nuestra socia es una madre trabajadora y emprendedora que va sacar adelante a su familia. La socia requiere el préstamo para comprar más menestras para luego vender. 


La socia se encuentra agradecido por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Melchora is a humble mother who is a member of the communal bank "Virgen Purificada - Angostura." Melchora is 70 years-old, widowed, and lives with her four children. Her children already work and are independent. Our member lives in the district of San Jerónimo in the community of Angostura, located south of the city of Cuzco. She works selling grains such as barley, wheat, and corn in the "Vino Canchon" market in the district of San Jerónimo. She has been working in this business for years and it has gone very well, thanks to all the effort she has invested in her work. Our member is a hard-working and enterprising mother that wants to get her family ahead. She needs this loan to buy more dried vegetables to later sell. Melchora is grateful for the opportunity offered by this institution and promises to make all payments on schedule.

Translated from Spanish by Kevin Credo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of dried vegetables for resale.

loans.name: Lucas

texts.es:
El señor Lucas R. Dávila, es una señor de 49 años de edad emprendedor de un negocio de joyería el cual comenzó con un capital inicial de C$10,000.00 que lo adquirió producto de un préstamo hace 15 años. Este negocio está ubicado en el Barrio Ayapal Managua, al oeste de la capital Managua. 

 El crédito solicitado es para invertir en capital de trabajo del negocio; como es la compra de oro y piedras preciosas, que se vende mucho en esta época del año debido a las promociones de estudiantes.

El es casado, con 3 hijos a su cargo 2 de ellos en edad escolar. Dice que antes de tener este negocio el trabajaba como obrero de construcción.

Lleva 9 créditos en  CEPRODEL a lo largo de 5 años los cuales ha invertido en su negocio con los que ha ido creciendo, diversificando su mercadería, esto gracias a los financiamientos otorgados por CEPRODEL.
texts.en:
Lucas R. Dávila is a 49 year old entrepreneur with a jewelry business. He started with C$10,000.00, which he acquired through a loan 15 years ago. His business is located in the Ayapal Managua neighborhood to the west of the capitol, Managua. The loan he is asking for is for work capital for his business. He will buy gold and precious stones, which he sells a lot of during this time of year because of the promotion of students. He is married, and he is raising three children. Two of them are school age. He says that before he had this business he worked as a construction worker. He has had nine loans over five years with Ceprodel. He used them to invest in his business. It has been growing, and he has been diversifying his merchandise. This is thanks to the loans given through Ceprodel.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy gold and precious stones

loans.name: Sonia

texts.es:
La socia Sonia es una humilde madre de familia que pertenece al banco comunal “VIRGEN PURIFICADA - ANGOSTURA”.    

La socia tiene 30 años de edad, es conviviente y tiene dos hijos varones. El hijo mayor estudia en el colegio y el menor estudia en el PRONEI (Programa Nacional de Educación Inicial). Nuestra socia esta acompañada de su esposo José. Ellos viven en el distrito de San Jerónimo en la comunidad de Angostura que se encuentra ubicada al sur de la ciudad del Cusco. La socia se dedica a la venta de frutas en el paradero final de los buses de la comunidad de Angostura. Ya son varios años que trabaja en el negocio y le ha ido muy bien gracias a todo el empeño que pone en su trabajo. Nuestra socia es una madre trabajadora y emprendedora que va sacar adelante a su familia. La socia requiere el préstamo para comprar más frutas como naranjas, plátanos, mandarinas, uvas, etc. 

La socia se encuentra agradecido por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Sonia is a humble mother who belongs to the Virgen Purificada – Angostura Communal Bank. She is 30, in a common law marriage, and has two sons. Her oldest son goes to school, and the youngest goes to PRONEI (National Program for Initial Education). She is accompanied by her husband, José. They live in the San Jerónimo district in the Angostura community, which is south of the city of Cusco. She sells fruit at the last bus stop in the Angostura community. She has been working in this business for several years. It has gone very well for her thanks to all of the effort she puts into her work. She is an enterprising and hard-working mother who wants to get her family ahead. She needs the loan to buy more fruit like oranges, bananas, tangerines, and grapes, etc. She is grateful for the opportunity of the loan, and she promises to pay it on time.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: By more fruit like oranges, bananas, tangerines, and grapes, etc.

loans.name: Maria Veronica

texts.es:
La señora María Verónica C. es una señora de 38 años de edad, emprendedora de un negocio de venta de ropa y calzado el cual comenzó con un capital inicial de C$10,000.00 que lo adquirió producto de un préstamo hace 12 años. Este negocio está ubicado en el mercado Israel lewite segunda entrada principal del mercado Managua. 

El crédito solicitado actualmente es para invertirlo en capital de trabajo del negocio como es la compra de  ropa para niños, pantalones juveniles, sandalias y ropa interior ya que en este mes es una buena temporada del año por lo que es fin de año y las ventas son buenas.
Ella ha trabajado con los créditos de ceprodel desde el año 2005 y en ese periodo de tiempo lleva 8 financiamientos  por parte de ceprodel los cuales ha invertido en su negocio.

Ella es madre soltera de 2 hijos a su cargo y ambos están en edad escolar.
texts.en:
María Verónica C. is a 38 year old entrepreneur with a business selling clothes and footwear. She started with C$10,000.00 that she got as a loan 12 years ago. This business is located at the second entrance in the Israel Lewites Market, which is the main market in Managua. The loan she is asking for is to invest working capital into her business. She will buy things like children’s clothes, pants for young people, sandals, and underwear. This month is a good time of the year because at the end of the year sales are good. She has worked with Ceprodel since 2005. In this time period she has had eight loans from Ceprodel, which she has invested in her business. She is a single mother raising two children. Both of them are school age.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Underwear, sandal, and children's shoe sales

loans.name: Bunheng

texts.en: Mr. Bunheng P., 37, and his wife, Mrs. Sreykea Cheng, 38, live on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married 13 years ago and have six children: one daughter and five sons. Four of them attend school and the other two are still too young. Bunheng has been a fisherman for ten years, while his wife has a grocery at her home in the village.

loans.use: To buy fishing nets for his fishing business and purchase more grocery items for his wife’s store.

loans.name: Nary

texts.en:
Mrs. Navy S., 30, and her husband, Mr. Srorn Sreng, 32, have been married for more than ten years. They have two children: one son and one daughter. Both of them currently attend school. The family lives in the area surrounding Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Navy has been a garment worker for more than eight years, while her husband has been a construction worker for more than ten years. Her kitchen is so small that the smoke blows into the house, making it both uncomfortable and unsafe for her family to sleep.

loans.use: To renovate the kitchen where she cooks.

loans.name: Maria Elena

texts.en:
Maria Elena C. is a 42 year old store owner who has been in the food business for many years.  She has eight children; the eldest is in college, two in high school and three in grade school.  Her husband Rodrigo, also 42, is a carpenter and is working overseas.  They live among the poor communities in Bagong Silang, Caloocan City.

Maria Elena has been into cooking and serving food to her neighbors until she opened a small variety store a few months ago.  She makes a net profit of P4,000.00 per month which she uses to sustain the studies of her children.
 
She has just finished repaying a previous loan with the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative which qualifies her for a new loan so she applied for a new loan in the amount of P14, 000.00.  This would be her tenth loan cycle with CCT.  She will use the loan proceeds to purchase additional merchandise for her store so she won’t need to come to the market as often.

Maria Elena works hard to sustain her children’s education, hand-in-hand with her husband working miles away.  She also dreams of owning a bigger grocery store.


About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: to purchase additional merchandise for her store

loans.name: Suos

texts.en: Mrs. Suos S., a longtime businesswoman who earns a living by selling distilling white wine. She resides with other family members, located in Kampong Chhnang Province. In addition, she also uses the leftover wine to raise a few pigs for extra income and typically earns $3 a day which helps her to buy food for her family. Suos S. is a married mother who has given birth to five children, one is married and four single. Two of her daughters are local tailors, while her husband, age 48, owns a machine to provide rice milling services for a profit. Suos S. is requesting a loan to purchase more tailoring materials for her daughters use to have enough supply to meet their customer’s needs.(Suos S. was not available at that time, so her husband is pictured instead.)

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Increase business capital

loans.name: Meas

texts.en: Meas S. is 31 years old and married to Prak Chanty, 37, a motor-taxi driver.  They have two teenage children.  Both of the children are students and are still dependent on their parents’ income.  Meas S. is a garment factory worker.  Recently, her husband has faced difficulties attracting customers for his motorcycle services and his income is declining because his motorcycle is frequently breaking down. Therefore, Meas S. is requesting a loan to replace her husband’s broken motorcycle taxi. With the rest of the loan she will repair her old house.

loans.use: To replace her husband’s broken motorcycle taxi

loans.name: Guillerma

texts.en:
This is Guillerma P., 54 years old, who lives and does business in Tala, Caloocan City. She lives with her husband Napoleon, 72, a retiree/pensioner, together with their three adult children.

Guillerma has a stall selling vegetables, fruits and rice. She has been in this business for seven years and has two paid helpers assisting her in the business. She earns P30, 000.00 a month which she saves to be able to venture into other businesses. She joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2005. Guillerma is now on her fifteenth loan cycle. She is expecting a new loan from the cooperative in the amount of P14, 000.00 as additional capital. With this fresh capital, she can purchase more assorted fruits and vegetables for her business. She hopes to establish a grocery store soon.

About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: purchase of more assorted fruits and vegetables for sale

loans.name: David

texts.es: El Sr. David, hace 4 años que se dedica al transporte publico con su propia movilidad auto, sale muy temprano a trabajar, desde las 6 de la mañana comienza a preparar su automovil  lavandolo para posteriormente salir a trabajar. Su esposa es ama de casa y es qiien atiende la unica hija que tienen, ella se dedica a la venta de material escolar pero solo a principios del año escolar. Él necesita el credito para hacer mejoras en su automovil;  todos los días sale a trabajar con su automovil en las diferentes calles y avenidas de nuestra ciudad. Él esta muy orgullosos del trabajo que esta haciendo porque sabe que de esta manera esta siendo un buen ejemplo para su familia, por lo que esta muy contento de contar con el apoyo que le brinda la institucion y esta muy comprometido en no fallar, para ser un ejemplo para su familia.
texts.en:
Señor David has been driving his own taxi for the last 4 years. He leaves very early in the morning for work. From 6 o-clock he begins to get his car ready, washing it before later leaving for work. His wife works in the house, caring for their only daughter. She sells school materials but only during the beginning of the school year. He needs a loan to make improvements to his car. Everyday he leaves for work in his taxi on the different roads in the city. He is very proud of the job he is doing because he knows that in this way he is being a good example for his family. For this, he is very content counting on the support Emprender provides and is committed to not defaulting so as to be a good example for his family.

Translated from Spanish by karl baumgarten, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase his business capital, improve his taxi

loans.name: Sophal

texts.en: Mrs. Sophal S. (shown in the photo), 39 and her husband, Mr. Veng Khut, 29, have been married since 1999 and have two children: one son and one daughter. Their daughter is a garment factory worker and their son attends school. They live in a small village along National Road number five approximately 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.  Mrs. Sophal S. has been selling fish for 10 years. She buys it from Prek Phnao market for resale in Kilomet 60 market. Her husband has been a construction worker for 10 years.  Sophal would like a loan of $500 to purchase a motorbike, to transport fish for her business.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for transporting fish for sale.

loans.name: Sem

texts.en: Sem S., 27, is a humble villager who earns a living as a local farmer. She plants various crops on her farmland and typically earns about $60 a month to help provide her family’s food needs. She is a married woman and the mother of a young child, who attends school. Her husband is a motorcycle taxi driver. Sem S. has requested a loan to buy a cow, that will help her plow her farmland. She hopes this cow will also provide her with many offsprings in the future.

loans.use: To buy a cow to plow her farmland

loans.name: Mario

texts.es: Mario, esposo y padre de 4 niños, trabaja en una MARMOLERIA, actividad que la realiza desde que era joven, es allí donde forjo sus habilidades de escultor, tallador y fabricador de mosaicos de piedra granito para pisos y gradas. También realiza la adaptación de lavaplatos y lavamanos en mesones de mármol,  realiza lapidas y cualquier tipo de trabajo que le sea requerido donde se utiliza el mármol o la piedra granito, que es traída de la ciudad de Cochabamba. Hace dos años que se independizo, actualmente cuenta con un ayudante y con la ayuda de su esposa que se han dedicado completamente a trabajar en su pequeña microempresa. Vive aun en una casa familiar que se encuentra bien ubicado, cuenta con mucha demanda ya que su trabajo es muy bien reconocido, puesto que sus mismos clientes son los que lo recomiendan con  muchas otras personas. En Un futuro desea tener una empresa bien consolidada, comprarse su propio vehiculo y ver a  sus hijos profesionales. Cliente antigüo en banco de emprendimiento, actualmente trabajando con crédito individual en nuestra institución.
texts.en:
Mario is a married father with 4 children and works in a marble and granite shop. He began this activity when he was young and it was then he shaped his abilities as a sculptor, engraver and builder of granite stone mosaics for floors and stairs. He made adaptations to kitchen and bathroom sinks in marble counters and made gravestones. He does whatever type of work that is brought to Cochabamba that requires marble or granite. He has worked independently for two years counting the years he worked as an assistant. With the help of his wife, he is now completely dedicated to his small business.

He lives in his family house that is well placed. His business is well recognized thanks to lots of demand. His customers are the same ones that recommended others to his business. In the future, he wishes he could have a stable business, buy his own car and see his children become professionals. He is a longstanding client of Emprender and is now an individual borrower at Emprender.

Translated from Spanish by karl baumgarten, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying raw materials, granite for counters

loans.name: Feliza

texts.en:
Feliza G., 34, is from the village of Aurora. She is married and has 2 adult children. To make a living, Feliza owns & operates a retail general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of products to the local community. Feliza has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Feliza joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and enhance her ability to engage in business activities. Feliza has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products for sale. Feliza is requesting a new loan of 23,000 PHP which, once again, will be used to purchase additional inventory. This loan will be Feliza's sixth loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products for sale

loans.name: Julio Cesar

texts.es:
En la foto sale la esposa del señor por razones laborales.

El señor Julio Cesar es una persona trabajadora desde hace años se dedica a conducir camiones de carga; es por ello que la mayor parte del tiempo se la pasa fuera de casa. Su esposa la señora Isabel Santos se queda en el hogar al cuidado de sus dos hijos y en fin de semana sale a vender ropa usada. Esta familia se da tiempo para convivir y aprovechar el tiempo lo mas que se pueda, este esfuerzo es con el fin de  dar mejor comodidad a sus hijos y una mejor calidad de vida. En el crédito pasado que se le otorgo fue para construir un cuarto enfrente de su casa ahora quieren poner las ventanas y protecciones para ya empezar habitar esa recamara, es por ello que necesita el apoyo de nosotros.
texts.en:
For work reasons, this photo is of the wife of the borrower. Mr. Julio Cesar is a hard worker and for years has been working driving freight trucks; for this reason he spends most of his time away from home. His wife, Mrs. Isabel Santos, stays at home to take care of their two children, and on the weekends leaves to sell used clothing. This family lives together and takes advantage of their time the most possible. This current effort is for the purpose of making their children more comfortable and giving them a better quality of life. The past loan granted to them was to add a room to the front of their home. Now, they want to put in the windows and protection features to make the room habitable. For this reason they need our help.

Translated from Spanish by Kevin Credo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Add windows and protection to a room.

loans.name: Betsy

texts.en:
Betsy M. is a 50 year old businesswoman who lives in Bagong Silang, Caloocan City. Her husband Errol, 56, drives a vehicle for a living. One of their six children is in high school and three are in grade school. Betsy manages her own general store and at the same time sews fabric trimmings to make rags. These combined activities give Betsy a net income of at least P2,500.00 a month. She has learned the value of saving for the future when she joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative. She uses her profits for the education of her children. Betsy applied for a new loan of P8, 000.00 with the cooperative, as additional capital to keep her businesses going.

About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: Purchase of more grocery items to sell

loans.name: Antonio

texts.es: Antonio D. L. C. es un negociante que tiene el anhelo D. prosperar cada día para darle una mejor calidad D. vida a su esposa; sus hijos ya son personas grandes que dependen D. si mismos, pero aun así quiere dejar un buen patrimonio para su familia. El desD. hace 18 años en su casa instalo un negocio D. abarrotes en el que fue creciendo poco a poco ahora su negocio es prospero, en este momento necesita capital para comprar mas mercancía por L. época naviD.ña donD. mucha gente D. fuera viene a su negocio para comprar cosas para su cena D. navidad. El quiere estar preparado ya que es el mes que obtiene más ganancias.
texts.en:
Antonio D. L. C. is a businessman who yearns to prosper every day so that he can give a better life to his wife. His sons are already grown and support themselves, but even so he wants to leave a good inheritance for his family. For the past 18 years, he has had a grocery store in his home. Bit by bit, the business grew, and it is now prosperous. Right now he needs capital to buy more merchandise for the Christmas season. At this time of year a lot of people come to his business to buy things for their Christmas dinners. Antonio wants to be prepared because December is the month he makes the most profit.

Translated from Spanish by Lydia Brantley, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Stock merchandise in store

loans.name: Maria Luisa

texts.es: La señora María Luisa R. quedo viuda desde muy joven, en ese matrimonio tuvo tres hijos pequeños, por los que saco adelante para darles una mejor calidad de vida. Esto ya fue hace años, sus hijos son mayores de edad en el que la apoyan económicamente y moralmente. Ella quiere ver que el piso de su casa se vea bien es por ello que desea poner vitropiso en sala-comedor. Para realizar su proyecto; necesita comprar el material y pagar mano de obra. Es por ello que recurre con nosotros para que se le apoye en su proyecto.
texts.en:
María Luisa R. was widowed at a very young age. She had three young children from her marriage. She brought them up properly to give them a better quality of life. This was years ago. Now her sons are grown and they support her economically and morally. She wants to ensure that the floor of her house looks good. She wants to put porcelain floor in her living/dining room. To do this, she needs to buy material and pay for labor. She is turning to us to ask for our support in her project.

Translated from Spanish by Lydia Brantley, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Put new floors in her home

loans.name: Presentacion

texts.en:
Presentacion G.'s main source of income comes from providing manicure and pedicure services in her community. She is 46 years old, married and has three school-age children. They are from the village of Ibung, Villa Verde, Nueva Vizcaya. Presentacion has been in her business for over three years now.

In 2009, Presentacion joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Presentacion is requesting a loan of 6000 Philippine pesos which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide her service. This will be her first loan from ASKI. She plans to use additional revenue to pay the tuition fees of her children.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide manicure/pedicure services

loans.name: Pech

texts.en:
Pech C., 36 years old, earns a living selling food for breakfast and lunch. She operates her food sales business all day and earns approximately $3.20 a day. She requests a loan to purchase a plot of her neighbor’s land in a good location for farming, which she will rent to farmers.

Pech C. is a good homemaker who stays at home to care for the children and do housework. She is married and blessed with three school-age children. Her husband is a security guard. She lives with her small family in Kampong Chhnang, Cambodia.

loans.use: To purchase a plot of neighbor’s land in a good location for farming

loans.name: Joan

texts.en:
Joan G. owns and operates a general clothing business. She is a 26-year-old single woman from Gonzaga St.,Tuguegarao City. Joan has been in her business for over two years and earns approximately 6,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month.

In 2009, Joan joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Joan is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. This will be her second loan from ASKI. She plans to use additional revenue to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and for working capital

loans.name: Sophea

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophea C., 26 and her husband, Mr. Chhum Choeung, 31, were married in 2004 and have two daughters. All of them are still young. They are living in a small village about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. 

Just two months ago, Sophea started a business selling food and coffee from her house.  Before this, she worked for a beauty salon. Her husband has been a construction worker in Phnom Penh for over 13 years.

loans.use: To buy additional materials for her business and to renovate the roof of her house.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita B., 56, and her husband Rogelio, 54, have been farmers for ten years. They have two children; one is in college and the other is in high school. The family lives in a farming village in Balubad, Silang, Cavite.

They were lucky to have acquired a farm lot in Silang, Cavite where the soil is very suitable for farming and upon which they grow pineapples and bananas. Teresita says they earn more than Php 8,000.00 a month in net profits, especially when there are few storms.

Teresita joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2006. She loves the camaraderie of the women entrepreneurs in her group. Now on her eighth loan cycle, she is applying for a new loan in the amount of Php 9,000.00 which she will use to purchase fertilizers, pesticides and other farming supplies for the next pineapple season.

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, pesticides and farming supplies.

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
Edna S. is from the town of Rio Del Grande Enrile, Cagayan. She is 56 years old, married and has five grown children. For over 15 years, Edna has been operating a general store. It is her main source of income and provides approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Edna joined ASKI to access their financial services and improve both her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Edna is requesting her second ASKI loan. This time she is asking for 35,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Las Solidarias Group

texts.es:
La señora jabiela pertenece al banco D. emprendimiento las solidarias, es un banco que esta en su 2do ciclo. La señora es la presidenta del banco esta conformado por 10 integarntes, es una persona joven y bastante dinamica su mercaderia es vendida en la ciudad D. Riberalta y se debe mencionar que esta estudiando odontologia en la universidad UDABOL y recibe el apoyo D. sus padres para cubrir las pensiones octavo semestre. con los ingresos que percibe por su negocio ella llega a cubrir los gastos personales que tiene.				
CARMEN, es la tesorera en el banco y ella trabaja medio tiempo como empleada del hogar en la zona San Pedro y medio tiempo es pasanaquera, vale decir que entrega mercaderia a requerimiento y la forma D. pago es a facilidades, tiene la modalidad D. pagos. Tiene un hijo y esta seperada D. su esposo, con el prestamo aumentará su capital, mejorando D. esta forma su calidad D. vida. Se observa en la señora muchos deseos D. superacion.						
MIRIAM, Es la secretaria del banco, ella tiene dos hijos y trabaja en la venta D. productos D. belleza, con el prestamo ha logrado comprar en cantidad sus productos que estaban en oferta como ser perfumes, desodorantes,talcos y otros, lo que permitirá mejorar sus ingresos. Vive en la casa D. sus padres y no paga alquileres, el esposo trabaja como taxista.
texts.en:
Sra. Jabiela is a member of the Communal Bank “Las Solidarias”, which is in its second loan cycle. She serves as the president of this Communal Bank, which consists of 10 members. Jabiela is a young and dynamic person who sells merchandise in the city of Riberalta. It should be mentioned that she is studying dentistry at UDABOL (University of Aquino Bolivia) and receives support from her parents to cover her room and board for the eighth semester. The income she generates from her business is used to cover her personal expenses.

Carmen is the treasurer of the Communal Bank. She works part-time as a housekeeper in the San Pedro area and part-time as a “pasanaquera”, which means she delivers merchandise and provides different payment options to her customers, including installment plans. Carmen has a son and is separated from her husband. Her loan will increase her capital and help improve her quality of life. She is very determined to succeed.

Miriam is the secretary of the Communal Bank. She has two children and sells beauty products. With her loan, she will purchase products in bulk that are being provided through special offers such as perfumes, deodorants, talcum powders, and other items. The additional inventory will help improve her income. Miriam lives in her parents’ house and does not pay rent. Her husband works as a taxi driver.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
Delia A. is from the village of Aurora. She is 55 years old, married and has two grown children. Delia has been selling her homemade foods for over five years. As her main source of income, her business generates approximately 2,000 PHP a month.

In 2006, Delia joined ASKI to access their financial services and improve both her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Delia has successfully repaid a previous ASKI loan of 15,000 PHP. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients for her food preparation business. Delia is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be the seventh loan taken out by Delia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to expand her business.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering.

loans.name: Lenie

texts.en:
Mrs. Lenie A. is from the village of Magsaysay in Baliangao, Misamis Occidental. She is 36 years old. She is married and blessed with 4 school-aged children. Lenie grows and sells rice. She has been in this business for more than 10 years and she earns PHP 4,000.00 (~ $87 USD) from her business each month. 

In 2001, Lenie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lenie has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Lenie is requesting a new loan of 30,000.00 PHP for her business.This will be Lenie's 14th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for her business

loans.name: Heb

texts.en:
Heb, 59, is married mother of three children. Two of her children are grown and have established their own households. Heb operates a medium grocery store in front of her home, selling cooking ingredients, as a means to support her family. Her husband helps her operate the store and also provides rice milling services for an additional profit.

To earn additional income, Heb will use her loan to buy piglets (and feed) to raise in her ready-built pigpen. She will use the rest of her loan to obtain more product inventory.

loans.use: To buy piglets (and feed) to raise.

loans.name: Estrelita

texts.en:
Estrelita A. is from the village of Malasin, Aurora. She is 59 years old, married and has seven grown children. Estrelita has been operating a general store for over six years. The business is her main source of income and generates approximately 2,000 PHP a month.

In 2006, Estrelita joined ASKI to access their financial services and to improve both her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Estrelita has successfully repaid a previous ASKI loan in the amount of 5,000 PHP. This previous loan was used to purchase inventory. Estrelita is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP to purchase additional inventory. This loan will be her seventh loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory (products to sell).

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Clarita's Group

texts.en:
Clarita C., 55, is from the village of Reina Mercedes. Clarita is the leader of an ASKI loan group consisting of five members. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Salucong.

Clarita is married and has three school-aged children. She has run a general store for over five years earning approximately 3,000 PHP a month as her sole income.

In 2007, Clarita joined ASKI to access their financial services and to improve both her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Clarita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Clarita is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will again be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her sixth ASKI loan. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to expand her business.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Simas

texts.en:
Mrs. Simas San, age 49 and her husband, Mr. Rophech S., age 54, were married 30 years ago and have four children: three sons and one daughter. Two of them are married and live outside the family home, one is fully employed and the youngest is in the fifth grade. The family is living along National Road Number Six about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Mrs. Simas San has been selling recycling materials for two years. Her husband has been driving a motor taxi for five years. She hopes to expand her recycling business in order to generate more income and support her family. Mrs. Simas San is requesting a loan of $300 to buy additional recycling materials for resale.

loans.use: To buy more recycling material for resale.

loans.name: Johnson

texts.en:
Johnson D. is a 45-year-old general store owner who lives in Modesta Village, San Mateo, Rizal.  He is married to Lilian Lila, 49, a teacher.  They have two school-aged children.

Johnson has been an entrepreneur for almost two decades.  His general store has been growing successfully though the years.  He also has a motorized tricycle.  He recently added selling purified drinking water in large containers.  He has also joined the bandwagon of entrepreneurs venturing into selling electronic load credits for mobile phones.  Combined, he earns more than $295 a month in net income.
 
He is now on his fifth loan cycle with the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative (one of Kiva's field partners) and has applied for a 11,000 PHP loan which he will use to purchase additional items to sell, including rice.  Johnson dreams of converting his small store to a grocery store someday. 



About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: purchase of additional merchadise to sell, including rice

loans.name: Carmen Ricarda

texts.es: La señora tiene una tienda de barrio en su domicilio, desde hace cinco años, sus clientes son generalmente de la zona, ella es muy trabajadora y la gente que la conoce le tienen mucha estima. La señora es viuda, tiene un hijo que depende directamente de ella, sus otros hijos ya son mayores y tienen sus propias familias. vive en casa propia. Es por segunda vez que tiene el credito con nuestra Institucion ha sido muy cumplida en sus pagos y por tal motivo se la volvio a dar el credito.
texts.en:
Sra. Carmen has a grocery store in her home that she has been managing for the past five years. Her customers are generally from the area. She is a hard worker who is well-respected by the people who know her. Carmen is a widow with one child who is still dependent on her. Her other children are grown and have families and homes of their own. This is the second time she has requested a loan from our Institution. Since she has satisfied the repayments of the previous loan, she will be provided with another one.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a variety of merchandise for her store

loans.name: Julie's Group

texts.en:
Julie, 36, is from the village of Annayatan Baggao, Cagayan. She is the leader of an ASKI loan group consisting of five members. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Annayatan group.

Julie is married and has three school-aged children. She has been operating a furniture and cabinet-making business for over five years. Her income is mainly derived from the making and selling of cabinets and wardrobe furniture to local businesses and community members. The business generates approximately 8,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Julie joined ASKI to access their financial services and improve both her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Julie is requesting her first loan from ASKI, in the amount of 5000 PHP, to purchase additional raw materials to expand her product offerings. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional raw materials to expand her product offerings.

loans.name: Jonalyn

texts.en:
Jonalyn P. lives in Sitio Tuburan, Hinigaran, Negros Occidental. She is 37 years old and married to Pelagio, who is a farmer. They have three children between the ages of 12 and 19. Two of them are still attending school and one is working in Manila, the capital city of the Philippines, and helps her parents support their family by sending money every month. Jonalyn wants her children to finish their studies, and she wants to help her husband earn income for their family.
 
To help her husband earn a living for the family, she put up a small general store adjacent to their house. At the start, her earnings were small, but it helped support their household expenses, and she saw that it had potential for expansion if she only had the necessary capital to fill her store with products to sell. This is why she joined the Kiva field partner, NWTF-Project Dungganon, in 1988, and with the additional capital from her loans, she is now able to earn a monthly income of about $213 a month, most of which she spends for their household expenses. She is also saving up for the education of her children. 

Now she is in her 18th loan cycle, borrowing 27,000 PHP as additional working capital for her general store.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros  Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of  thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Sarin

texts.en:
Mr. Sarin P., 38, and his wife Mrs. Sokha Born (both pictured), 35, have been married for 22 years and have five children: two sons and three daughters. Four of them are in school and the youngest stays at home. The family lives along national road number one about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh. 

Sarin and his wife have been farming for 15 years. They grow vegetables on their farmland in the village. The couple doesn’t have enough capital to maintain their vegetable farm, so Sarin is asking for his first loan of $500 to pay for plowing fees and to purchase fertilizer and pesticide.

loans.use: To pay for plowing fees, and purchase fertilizer and pesticide for his farming business.

loans.name: Um

texts.en:
Mrs. Um B., age 53, grows rice and earns about $4 a day. She is also a civil service officer who works in the National Information Communications Technology Development Authority (NiDA). She is a married woman who has given birth to four children who are married and live independently. Her husband stays at home to assist with her in planting rice. 

Um B. has been buying a farming machine on credit, but she does not have enough money to repay the current owner of the machine, so she is requesting a loan from Kiva’s field partner, HKL. She plans to use some of the loan to grow rice.

loans.use: To buy a farming machine

loans.name: Debbie's Group

texts.en:
Debbie B. is from the village of Burgos. She is 52 years old. Debbie is the leader of a 8-member loan group sponsored by ASKI. Although each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is "Caliguian Center."

Debbie is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Debbie owns and operates a general store where she sells a variety of products in the local community. Debbie has been engaged in her business for over 13 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2006, Debbie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Debbie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. She used her previous loan to buy products to sell. Debbie is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP to buy products to sell. This will be Debbie's 7th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy products to sell

loans.name: Thoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Thoeun K., age 40, has been married to Mr. Khoeun Khen, age 42, since 1990. They have six children, four sons and two daughters. Two of the children are married and live in their own homes, three children attend school, and the youngest one is still stays at home. They live in a small village along National Road Number Five, about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh. Thoeun has borrowed from Kiva through MAXIMA once before. 

Mrs. Thoeun and her husband are farmers. They grow rice and lotus fruit on their farm and sell them at the market in Phnom Penh. Her two married children are garment factory workers. Every day they must travel to and from work, which is expensive, because they do not have their own transportation. Therefore, Thoeun is requesting her second loan of $800 to help her children buy a motorcycle to commute to work.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her children to ride to work.

loans.name: Roberta

texts.en:
This is Roberta R., a 42-year-old entrepreneur from Camarin, Caloocan City.  One of her three children is in high school.  Her husband, Roberto, age 47, works as a plumber.

Roberta buys and sells frozen processed meats, such as longanisa (a local sausage), embutido (meat loaf), and hotdogs. Her products appeal a lot to her customers, especially working mothers who pack her products in their children's school lunch boxes. She is thankful to the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative for providing her loans, which she has used to buy her products in bulk and stores them in the freezer. She now earns more than P5,000.00 a month in net income, but her earnings sometimes vary depending on the supply and demand for frozen products.

Roberta applied for a new loan of P12,000.00 from CCT so she can re-stock her frozen supplies. She wishes to see all her children finish their studies.

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To buy more processed frozen goods to sell

loans.name: Lerma's Group

texts.en:
Lerma D. C. is from the village of Taguntungan Baggao in Cagayan. She is 42 years old. Lerma is the leader of a 5-member loan group sponsored by ASKI. Although each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is "Taguntungan Group."

Lerma is married and has 6 school-aged children. To make a living, Lerma raises and sells pigs. Lerma has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Lerma joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lerma is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be Lerma's first loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Phoem

texts.en: Phoem Y., age 31, has been growing rice in her village for many years. She learned farming from her grandparents who died many years ago. Her husband, Mr. Leang Chanthy, who appears in the photograph, is 40 years old. He also leaves home to buy pigs from rural people and transports them to his house to slaughter and sell. This couple has been married for many years and is blessed with three school-aged children, all of whom are still dependent on their parents. Because their house is old and damaged, Phoem Y. is requesting a loan to repair it.

loans.use: To repair her old house

loans.name: Nora

texts.en:
Mrs. Nora P. is from the village of Magsaysay in Baliangao, Misamis Occidental. She is 37 years old. She is married and blessed with 3 school-aged children. She grows and sell rice in the local  community. She earns PHP 4,000.00 monthly from her business. 

In 2006, Nora joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Nora is requesting a new loan of PHP 20,000.00 to use as additional capital for her business.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for her rice business

loans.name: Estrellas Uno Group

texts.es:
Banco D. Emprendimiento: LAS ESTRELLAS UNO  fue fundado el 03 D. AGOSTO del 2008, a iniciativa D. un grupo D. señoras que tienen un pequeño negocio y desean surguir en un negocio. Se encuentra situado en el B/ SAN FRANCISCO NORTE. El grupo  esta en su 4to ciclo, compuesto por 10 personas; en el grupo hay señoras que se dedican a la venta D. bijouteria, comida, costura y sastreria, promotoras D. cosmeticos, venta D. pastillas y refresco D. mocochinchi (durazno seco), venta D. helados, venta D. pan, pintado en tela; son actividades que necesitan creditos rapidos. Las Señoras estan conformes D. trabajar con Emprender, porque aprendieron ahorrar y tener mucha responsabilidad, respeto y al mismo tiempo compartir con sus amigas y vecinas cada quincena. 			
La Sra.Sonia, es Presidenta del grupo, es socia antigua, es la presidenta del Banco D. Emprendimiento. La Sra. Sonia nacio  en Montegudo Chuquisaca, radica en Santa Cruz hace ya varios años. Ella se dedica a alquilar sillas y mesas D. plastico para fiestas y acontemientos sociales, ademas tambien venD. cds en su domicilio, lo que le da tiempo para atender a su familia mientras trabaja, es una persona amigable y muy dinamica, ademas D. ello es una persona cumplida y responsable en el grupo y la oportunidad que le brinda Emprender es muy importante para ella.Tambien ella es unas D. las lideres del grupo y hace que todas cumplan con sus cuotas. Ayuda al sustento D. su hogar con los ingresos que percibe.			
La Sra. Hortencia es socia antigua del Banco D. Emprendimiento Las Estrellas Uno. Nacio en Arani, Cochabamba, se dedica hace 8 años a la venta D. verduras en el Mercado Abasto ubicado en el 3er anillo, bijouteria y animales,  tambien  realiza labores D. casa mientras que su esposo trabaja como albañil en diferentes partes D. la ciudad. Ella es muy responsable dentro del grupo. Con los ingresos que percibe ayuda al sustento D. su familia y ademas D. considerarla que  es  responsable y cumplida en el grupo. La Sra. es unas D. las fundadoras del grupo y cliente muy antigua D. Emprender.			
La Sra. Silvia es socia del Banco D. Emprendimiento Las Estrellas Uno, se dedica a la venta D. hamburguesas todas las noches en su domicilio en el Barrio San Francisci Norte, frente a la parada D. los micros D. la Linea 5 por lo que aprovecha esto para vender  a los choferes D. esta linea, ella comienza su trabajo bien temprano cuando sale a comprar el pan y hamburguesas y lo que necesita para su venta; comienza vender a las 4:00 pm hasta las 10:00 pm, su trabajo mayormente es preparar y vender las hamburguesas en su domicilio. La Sra es fundadora en el grupo  y la  oportunidad que le brinda el Banco D. Emprendimiento Las Estrellas es muy importante para ella.
texts.en:
The Communal Bank “Las Estrellas Uno” was founded on August 3, 2008, as an initiative by a group of ladies who wanted to continue with their small businesses. The Communal Bank is located in the neighborhood of San Francisco Norte. The group is in its fourth loan cycle and consists of 10 people. The women of the group are involved in retail businesses selling costume jewelry, food, cosmetics, medicines, mocochinchi (a beverage maD. with dried peaches), ice cream, painted fabrics, as well as offering services such as sewing and tailoring. They need access to credit immediately. These ladies are happy to be working with Emprender because they have learned how to save and take on many responsibilities. At the same time, they respect one another and have time to catch up with their friends and neighbors every two weeks.

Sra. Sonia is the president of the Communal Bank and a long-time member. She was born in Montegudo Chuquisaca, but has lived in Santa Cruz for several years. Sonia rents out plastic chairs and tables for parties and social gatherings. She also sells CDs out of her home, which gives her time to look after her family while she is working. In addition to being a friendly a dynamic person, Sonia has demonstrated that she is one of the most accomplished and responsible members of the group. This opportunity that Emprender has provided is very important to her. As one of the leaders of the group, she has satisfied all of her payments. The income she earns allows her to maintain her household.

Sra. Hortencia is another long-time member of “Las Estrellas Uno” Communal Bank. She was born in Arani, Cochabamba. Hortencia has been selling vegetables for eight years at the Abasto Market in the third section where rings, costume jewelry, and animals are also sold. She takes care of the household duties while her husband works as a mason in different parts of the city. Hortencia is a very responsible member in her group. With the income she earns, she is able to support her family. She is considered to be one of the most responsible and accomplished members of the group. She is a founding member of the Communal Bank and a long-time client of Emprender.

Sra. Silvia is a member of “Las Estrellas Uno” Communal Bank who sells hamburgers every night at her home in the neighborhood of San Francisco Norte. Her house is located in front of the bus stop for Route #5, so she is able to sell to all of the drivers. She begins her work early in the day when she leaves to go buy bread and meat that she needs for making hamburgers. Silvia begins selling at 4pm and ends at 10pm. Her work primarily consists of preparing and selling the hamburgers from her home. Silva is the founder of “Las Estrellas” group, which has provided many opportunities that have been very important to her.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital for their respective businesses

loans.name: Anselma's Group

texts.en:
Anselma L. is from the village of Sampaguita Solana, Cagayan. She is 43 years old. Anselma is the leader of a 16-member loan group sponsored by ASKI. Although each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for repaying the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is "Sampaguita Group."

Anselma is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Anselma owns and operates a general store where she sells a variety of different products in the local community. Anselma has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2005, Anselma joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Anselma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from ASKI. She used her previous loanto buy products to sell. Anselma is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP to buy products to sell. This will be Anselma's 10th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy products to sell

loans.name: Ma. Devy

texts.en:
Becoming a widow has not stopped Ma. Devy D. C. from continuing to work hard for the betterment of her family. At 45 years of age, with two children who are 21 and 22 years old, Devy lives in the village of Brgy. Tuig, Hinigaran, Negros Occidental.

Many years ago, Devy wanted to help her husband pay for their family expenses, so she put up a general store and it lessened the financial burden on her husband. As her store grew, she needed additional capital to sustain its growth – this is why she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2003. It enabled her to expand her store operations even more. When her husband died, she was so grief-stricken even her business was affected for some time, but then she realized that she still had her children to support and to live for, so she focused all of her attention in this new direction and moved on with her life and her business.

Because of her invigorated efforts, her business began to grow again and with the help of loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, she now earns a minimum of 15,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. She saves most of her income for the security and future of her children after spending for household expenses. Her previous loan of 18,000 PHP was used as additional working capital for her general store. Now that it is fully repaid, she is applying for a new loan, borrowing the same amount of 18,000 PHP for her eighth loan cycle which she intends to use in her general store as additional working capital to buy more products to sell.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon(a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon – a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of the community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: For additional working capital

loans.name: Thach

texts.en:
Mr. Thach T., 45, and his wife, Mrs. Thach Houn, 46, (pictured together) have been married for over 25 years and have six children: two sons and four daughters. They are living along national road number one about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh. 

Thach has been a mason for 12 years, while his wife has been selling vegetable for 10 years. He is asking for his first loan of $600 to help his wife to purchase vegetables for her business.

loans.use: To purchase vegetables to sell

Mary Rose has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Mary Rose joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mary Rose has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Mary Rose is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Mary Rose from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.
