loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita C. is a 58-year-old widow and single mother to her two children. One child is in high school and the other is in grade school.  They live in Paligawan, Silang, Cavite.  

Nenita owns a general store that has been around for 20 years.  Through the years, her general store has grown steadily.  She now earns P6,800.00 a month. She uses her profit to support her children’s education and their daily needs.   

She is now taking her 10th loan from the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative, which she joined in 2006.  She has recently applied for a new loan of P10,000.00.  She will use the loan to purchase more items to sell at her general store.  Nenita dreams of improving her general store to become a big grocery store someday.  



About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery items to sell

loans.name: Editha Tangan Group

texts.en:
Editha T. is from the village of Andarayan North Solana, Cagayan. She is 48 years old. Editha is the group leader of a 9-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Andarayan North Group.

Editha is married and has six school-aged children. To make a living, Editha operates a family member's specialized retail store selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Editha has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2004, Editha joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Editha has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. Editha is requesting a new loan of 19,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the eighth loan taken out by Editha from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support financially immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Maria Virginia

texts.es: La Señora Maria Virginia se dedica, hace 5 años a la venta D. comida, ella prepara 20 almuerzos al dia que lleva a la Fabrica San Aurelio, además D. eso es profesora D. musica; se levanta muy temprano todos los dias para ir a comprar la carne que necesita para preparar sus alumuerzos que debe repartir hasta las 12:00 horas del mediodia en la que los trabajadores salen a comer. Tomo la decision D. aumentar su capital D. trabajo y  D. comprar más cajitas D. almuerzo y D. una heladera para mantener mejor los viveres que compra para los almuerzos, es por eso que ha accedido a un credito con EMPRENDER, ella esta muy orgullosa del trabajo que esta haciendo puesto que debe dar el ejemplo a sus hijas que estan en secundaria, por lo que esta muy contenta D. contar con el apoyo que le brinda la institucion y esta muy comprometida en no fallar, para ser un ejemplo para su familia. Desea con el tiempo poder colocar una pension familiar en su casa y vender cena tambien para poder mejorar sus ingresos y darle mejores oportunidades a su familia.
texts.en:
For 5 years, Señora Maria Virginia has been selling food, preparing 20 lunches a day that she carries to the San Aurelio factory. In addition to this, she is a music teacher. She gets up very early each day to go to buy the meat that she needs to make her lunches; she distributes them at noon to the workers who leave the factory to eat. She maD. the decision to increase her working capital and to buy more lunch containers and a cooler to better maintain the perishables that she buys for the lunches. For this reason she has approached EMPRENDER for a loan. She is very proud of the work she is doing, since she must set a good example for her daughters who are in secondary school. For this reason she is very pleased to have the support of the institution, as she is committed to succeed so as to be an example for her family. She hopes that over time she will be able to rent out rooms in her house and also sell dinner so that she can improve her income and give greater opportunities to her family.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to increase capital

loans.name: Hout

texts.en: S., age 45, lives in the province of Kampong Chhnang. To earn a living, S. built a small store located along the street where she sells breakfast food to people who are villagers or passer-by. Day to day, she always wakes up in the early morning to either cook food or prepare places to sit before she starts selling her foods. Another source of family income is from her husband’s business. He drives a motorbike taxi. S. is married and blessed with four children, two are married and two are single. One of her daughters contributes to the family by selling grilled meatballs. S. wants a loan to replace her husband’s taxi, which is not attractive to his customers.

loans.use: To replace her husband’s taxi

loans.name: Ledenila's Group

While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Ledenila is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Ledenila owns & operates a business planting & harvesting a variety of vegetables for sale. Ledenila has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Ledenila joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ledenila has successfully repaid a previous loan of 30,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. Ledenila is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the ninth loan taken out by Ledenila from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Genaro Carlos

texts.es: El sr. Carlos es un cliente muy antiguo de la agencia, trabaja con nosotros desde el año 2005, cancelando siempre sus pagos puntualmente. Se dedica a la confección de chamarras, buzos deportivos y chalecos para niños y adultos, lleva ya 11 años en este rubro; tiene también un minibús pequeño con el cual trabaja por la mañana muy temprano y por la tarde casi al anochecer, su esposa viaja a distintos departamentos, como Potosi y Oruro, llevando la mercadería de su esposo, ambos se apoyan mutuamente. Sus hijos le ayudan a costurar y también estudian. El crédito será invertido en la compra de telas para la confección de busos para niños para las fiestas navideñas.
texts.en:
Mr. Carlos is an old client of the agency, he has worked with us since 2005 and always repays his loans promptly. Carlos makes jackets, sport suits and vests for adults and children. He has been in this line of work for 11 years. He also has a minibus with which he works in the early morning as well as in the evening towards nightfall. His wife travels to different departments like Potosi and Oruro, selling her husband’s merchandise, they support each other. His children help him with the sewing and they are also studying. The loan will be invested in the buying of fabrics for children’s sport suits for the Christmas season.

Translated from Spanish by Lauren Jackson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy fabric

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.en:
Rosalie L. lives in Ilayang Pulo, Silang, Cavite.  She is 43 years old.  Her husband Recto is a driver.  They have six children, one of whom is already working and the rest are still in school. Rosalie manages a plant nursery where she takes care of and sells ornamental and flowering plants.  This business has been providing for her family for many years.  She also manages the operation of their motorized tricycle transport.  She earns P14,000.00 a month.  

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative has been her source of business capital since she joined. It has provided her the necessary assistance she needs for the continuity of her business.  She has just finished repaying her previous loan with the Cooperative.  She used the loan to buy plant pots and fertilizers.  From her profits, she was able to buy a service vehicle and another tricycle.

Rosalie applied for a new loan of P17,000.00.  She will use the funds to buy more plant seedlings, organic fertilizers and plant pots.  She hopes to put up another nursery in the next town soon.  


About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase plant pots and fertilizers and maintain their tricycle

loans.name: Nun

texts.en:
Mrs. Nun C. is 60 years old and her husband, Mr. Ret Toun, is 66 years old. They live along national road number one about 35 kilometers from Phnom Penh. The couple was married in 1965 and has five children: three sons and two daughters. Four of their children are married and live outside the family house and the other is a garment factory worker. Though the couple is elderly, they are still strong enough to work. 

Nun and her husband are farmers. They grow rice on their farmland in the village. Farming is the main business for supporting themselves, so Nun is requesting her first loan of $300 to purchase fertilizer, oil fuel and pesticides to use on her rice farm.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, oil and pesticides for her farming business.

loans.name: Divina's Group

texts.en:

While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

loans.name: Epifania

She has a monthly income of 7,850 PHP from her pension and monthly allotment from her children. In 2009, Epifania joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation. She is requesting a loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase housing materials. This loan will be her first from PMPC. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.name: Ben

texts.en: Most of the Cambodian people earn a living as farmers. One of these people, Ben S., 40, is a low-income farmer living in Kampong Chhnang Province. She is a good and determined mother who has tried to feed her four children since they were very young. Her husband is a local teacher and helps her plant rice when he is not teaching. In the past, Ben S. always rented a neighbor’s cow to help plow her farmland and right now, she hopes to own a cow. To cut the rental cost, Ben S. requested a Kiva loan to buy a cow for her farming activities.

loans.use: To buy a cow for her farming activities

loans.name: Leticia

texts.en:
Leticia T. is from the village of Sinippil, Reina Mercedes. She is 46 years old. Leticia is married and has 7 adult-aged children. To make a living, Leticia owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising chickens for sale. Leticia is just starting this business.

In 2009, Leticia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leticia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Leticia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Marivie

texts.en:
This is Marivie P., a 27-year-old young entrepreneur who lives and does business in Silang, Cavite. Her husband Joenard, 29, is a driver-businessman. All of their three young children are now in grade school.

For five years now, Marivie has been in the coconut business. She buys young coconut fruits directly from farmers and she retails them. She has a fruit stand along the highway by-pass leading to Tagaytay City – a local tourist destination in the province. Marivie also sells coconut by-products like pure coco vinegar and coco wine. She earns a net monthly income of P45,000.00 from this business.

Being a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative has helped her to grow her business. She is now applying for a new loan in the amount of P10,000.00 as additional capital for buying more coconuts.

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase more coconut fruits

loans.name: Senbi

texts.en:
Senbi H. is 39 years old and lives with his wife and four children in Bayan-Olgii province, one of Mongolia's western provinces. Two of his children go to local secondary schools, and his two youngest children go to a local kindergarten. Senbi has a small business in meat retail. He rents a small stall at the local food market and sells mainly mutton and beef there. He mostly purchases cattle and sheep from local herders at wholesale prices and slaughters them for sale. As he has been in the business for a few years, he has gained a good network of people in the local meat retail business, which helps him a lot to do well.

Senbi says that in the future, he would like to expand his business and own an underground storage where he would like to keep the meat until the meat price spikes up. He requests a loan to purchase more cattle and sheep for his business.

loans.use: To purchase more cattle and sheep

loans.name: Trebol De 4 Hojas Group

texts.es: El Banco Trebol D. 4 Hojas es una D. las bancas que se sostiene en base a sus socias antiguas, las socias D. la banca se dedican a la venta D. celulares, pintores, lavado D. autos, Tienda D. Abarrotes, venta D. verduras, banca que actualmente se encuentra en el 3er ciclo, durante su permanencia no presentaron problemas, siempre cumpliendo sus cuotas. Los creditos otorgados lo invirtieron en la compra D. mercaderia, aumento D. capital en sus negocios, ya que sus negocios llega a ser uno D. los principales sustentos para su familia la mayoria D. las socias tienen recursos economicos bajos que con los creditos otorgados van mejorando su calidad D. vida. ANTONIA, es una D. las socias que conformo la banca trebol D. 4 hojas, es una D. las fundadoras, y representante D. la banca como presidenta, actualmente sigue  como representante D. la banca Comunal, en su permanencia la señora ha aprendio a ser una D. las socias mas ahorradoras dentro su grupo, su actividad es la venta D. flores, velas, en las iglesias, es muy exigente con sus compañeras los creditos. CINTHYA LICETTE, es la secretaria D. la banca Comunal, es una D. las socias que integra a la banca como fundadora, en su permanenecia demostro mucha responsabilidad, en sus pagos D. cuotas, su actividad es la venta D. celulares, el credito solicitado lo necesita para la compra D. mercaderia. ANA, socia que cumple la funcion D. tesorera D. la banca, al igual que otras socias, es una D. las fundadoras D. la banca, la socias se dedica a trabajos con vidrio, el credito lo invertira para la compra D. material D. trabajo, en la banca aprendio a estar en comunidad con las socias siempre puntual, a la hora D. pagar cuotas.
texts.en:
The Trebol D. 4 Hojas Bank is one of the banks that fundamentally supports its older members. Them members of the bank sell cell phones, are painter, wash cars, run a general store, and sell vegetables. This bank is now it its third loan cycle, and during their past cycles there have not been any problems, always making their full payments. The solicited loans will be used for the purchase of merchadise and for building capital for their businesses in order to allow their business to be one of the main financial providers for their families. The majority of the members have low financial resources, and their loans would improve their quality of life. ANTONIA is one of the members of the Trebol D. 4 Hojas Bank, she is one of the founders, and she is serving as the bank representative and president and is continuing to serve as the representative of the Communal bank. During her time with the bank, she has learned to be the highest saving member of her group. Her business is the sale of flowers and candles in churches. She very demanding of her fellow borrowers. CINTHYA LICETTE is the secretary of the Communal Bank. She is one of the members who helped found the bank, and in her tenure, she has shown herself to be very responsible with her repayments. Her business is cell phone sales and she is soliciting this loan to buy merchandise. ANA is the member who serves as the treasurer of the bank. Like the other members, she is a founder of the bank. Her business is working with glass and she will use this loan for working material. As part of this bank, she has learned to work well with her peers and to always be punctual, arriving at the right time for payments.

Translated from Spanish by Julia Kastner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise, material, and tools for working with glass

loans.name: Donna Joy

Donna Joy V. is from the village of Aurora. She is 22 years old. Donna Joy is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Donna Joy owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling food. While not the only means of generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling fish balls and other dimsums to the local community. Donna Joy is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Donna Joy from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business.

loans.name: Mara

texts.en:
Mrs. Mara N., 44, and her husband, Mr. Sok Morm, 41, (pictured together) were married over 20 years ago and have three children: one son and two daughters. All of them are in school. The family lives along National Road Number One approximately 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Mara has been raising pigs and producing rice wine for five years. Her husband is assisting his wife in the business. Mara is asking for her first loan of $500 to buy food for her pigs.

loans.use: Purchase food for pigs

loans.name: Maamuu

texts.en: Maamuu B. is 41 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Uvs province, one of Mongolia's western provinces. His 14-year-old son and 13-year-old daughter both go to a local high school. Maamuu is a talented and experienced carpenter. He makes various home furniture and other wooden items. After he left his job at the local power station, he decided to start his own small business in what he does best - carpentry. He has been making furniture since 2004 and he is very well known in the town for his talent and the furniture he makes. Maamuu would like to expand his business, as more locals want to purchase his furniture. He requests a loan to purchase more wood and other necessary materials to make wooden furniture.

loans.use: Purchase wood for furniture

loans.name: Kong

texts.en: Kong S. is a 43-year-old married woman who currently resides in the territory of Kampong Chhnang, a province of Cambodia. She is a tailor for a garment industry and started more than four years ago. Kong S. is blessed with four children. One of her children is married and has started a new home. The other three children are single. One of her daughters works in the garment factory. Her husband is a civil servant officer for a ministry. Kong S. and her family have faced difficulties traveling to work or anywhere else, because they don’t have a vehicle. Because of this problem, Kong S. is applying for a loan to add to her little savings in order to buy a motorcycle, which she will use for the family's transportation needs.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle

loans.name: Sina

texts.en:
Mrs. Sina C., 19, and her husband Mr. Hongleng C., 19, have been married since 2008 and have a young daughter. The family is living on an Island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. 

Sina and her husband have been growing ginger on their farm since they were married. Before, she was a silk weaver as well. She is requesting her first loan of $100 to help purchase ginger seed.

loans.use: To buy seed to grow ginger.

loans.name: Edmundo

texts.es: Edmundo, tiene un vehículo (Vagoneta Toyota)con el cual trabaja todos los días, brindando un servicio a la población en general. Vive en una casa en Anticrético, el deseo más grande que tienen es comprarse su propia casa, para de esa manera   dejar de vivir en anticresis, ya que le resulta algo incomodo pòr no poder realizar algunos cambios en la casa por no ser de su propiedad. Cuenta con algo de capital para la compra de su vivienda, capital que lo tienen invertido en el anticrético, por un monto de  seis mil dólares americanos ($us 6.000.-)su esposa se dedica a la venta de comidas en la misma casa para de esta manera poder ayudar en su núcleo familiar. Tienen dos hijos a quienes sustentan. Don Edmundo empezó a trabajar desde muy joven ya lleva en el rubro 15 años y con su propio vehículo  1 año y medio, hoy en día trabaja más tranquilamente con su vehículo ya que no tienen que entregar renta diaria a nadie solo trabajar para él y su familia. El sueño de tener su `propia vivienda no está muy lejana puesto que ahora gana  más dinero con su propio vehículo para aumentar el capital que tiene invertido en el anticrético.
texts.en:
Edmundo has a Toyota station wagon, which he employs every day to offer service to the greater community. He lives in a house in Anticrético. His greatest desire is to buy his home, so that he can get out of antichresis (possession and enjoyment of mortgaged property by mortgagee in lieu of interest payments) because it is inconvenient for him to not be able to make changes to his house because it is not his property. He does have some capital to use towards his home, capital which he is currently using to pay off the antichresis, but he needs six thousand American dollars ($6,000). His wife sells food out of their house to help support their nuclear family. They have two dependent children. Don Edmundo started to work when he was very young, and he has been working in this field for 15 years, with his own car for one and half years. Now, his work in his own car is easier because they don't have to pay daily rent to anyone; he can just work for himself and his family. His dream of his own house is not far off, because he now earns more money with his own vehicle, which he can use to pay off his mortgage.

Translated from Spanish by Julia Kastner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of wheels and other vehicle improvements

loans.name: Nasanjargal

texts.en: Nasanjargal M. is 47 years old and lives with her husband and five children in Uvs province, one of Mongolia's western provinces. She has three daughters and two sons, ranging in age from eight to 22. Her oldest daughter is 22 years old and a fourth-year-student in a local pedagogical university. The other four children all go to secondary schools in town. Nasanjargal has a small shoe-making business with her husband. Her husband is a talented sewer and makes traditional warm winter shoes. She used to work in a local shoe factory until 1995. After she quit her job, she started her own small business with her husband. Many of their customers are herders who need very warm shoes during harsh winter in which temperature can drop to -40 Celsius easily. In early winter, the demand for winter shoes spikes and they hire temporary employees to meet the local demand for shoes. Nasanjargal requests a loan to purchase shoe materials for their business.

loans.use: To purchase shoe materials

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
Delia S. is from the village of Sinippil, Reina Mercedes. She is 28 years old. Delia is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Delia owns & operates a business selling vegetables. Delia has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 280 daily net income for these activities.

In 2008, Delia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Delia is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase some materials for their house. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Delia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase some materials for their house

loans.name: Van

texts.en:
Mr. Van C., 66, has been driving a motor taxi for 10 years. His wife has been selling food in front of her house for one year. They are living along national road number one, approximately 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Unfortunately, Van’s motorbike is old and does not work well. Van is asking for his first loan of $300 to repair his motorbike and continue working. He will also use a part of the loan to help his wife build a storefront for her business.

loans.use: To repair his motorbike & build a storefront for his wife’s business.

loans.name: Khourn

texts.en: Khourn M. is 50 years old, married and the mother of four children, three of whom are married and one single. Her husband, Soam Saran is 51 years old and is a fisherman who catches fish along the river. Khourn M. raises pigs as well as cultivates rice to earn a living and earns around $2 each day. Her business is running smoothly and is profitable because she has many years of experience in her business. To make the business more successful with much income, Khourn M. is requesting a loan for extra capital to grow rice or raise pigs. She hopes to use the rest of the loan to buy more tools for her husband’s fishing.

loans.use: To grow rice or raise pigs

loans.name: Myla

texts.en:
Myla A. is a 40-year-old entrepreneur living in Silang, Cavite.  Her husband, Librado, 41, is a volunteer member of the local community peacekeepers.  Two of their three children are now college students and the youngest is in high school.

Myla owns and manages a general store which she started ten years ago.  She also sells electronic load credits for mobile phones.  Myla is also into buying and selling jewelry, which she offers to customers on an installment basis.  She also finds time to sell boneless bangus (milk fish).   She is now earning around $860 a month from these business activities. She uses her profits to help provide the daily basic needs of the family, especially her children’s education.  

In 2007, she came to know about the Kiva field partner, the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative, and became a member.  She is now on her 8th loan cycle.  She is asking for a new loan in the amount of 50,000 PHP to purchase more grocery items to sell at her store.

Just like many others, it’s been her desire to find her way out of poverty, and she sees education as the best tool to equip her children for their future.  That is why she works hard to support their studies.


   
About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: to purchase more grocery items to sell

loans.name: Sun

texts.en:
Sun V. is 44 years old, married and the mother of eight children, one of whom is married and seven who are still single. Two of them are garment workers and another two assist her in weaving baskets. Her husband is named Yorng Hoeun, and he is 48 years old.

This family depends on a small handicraft business, weaving bamboo baskets to sell, for a daily income. They have also cultivated a rice crop. Sun V. is taking out her loan to hire a laborer to harvest her mature rice and to buy more raw materials for weaving baskets.

loans.use: To hire a laborer to harvest her rice and to buy more raw materials for weaving baskets

loans.name: Karen Lizeth

texts.es: Karen Lizeth R. R.  de 32 años de edad, reside en el departamento de Ahuachapán junto a su esposo y sus tres hijos menores de edad. Ella posee una tienda de productos perecederos, negocio el cual les ha permitido tener una vida estable, Karen desea ampliar su negocio y poder surtirlo con bebidas frías, ya que estas son muy vendidas en el lugar en el cual vive, es por esto que solícita un préstamo para poder tener la capacidad económica de comprar dichas bebidas.
texts.en:
Karen Lizeth R. R. is 32 years old, lives in the Ahuachapán district with her husband and three young children. She owns a perishable goods store, a business which has allowed her to lead a stable life. Karen wants to enlarge her business and be able to supply it with cold drinks, since these sell well in the area where she lives. This is why she is seeking a loan to be able to have the economic ability to buy these drinks.

Translated from Spanish by Julia Kastner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cold drinks

loans.name: Meach

texts.en:
Meach S. weaves bamboo baskets to sell. She sells her finished products to buyers who come directly to her house. She makes over 50 sets of baskets before selling out. She also orders baskets from other villagers, and sells them to make additional income. Her husband helps her buy the raw materials and to sell the baskets.

Recently, Meach sold all her baskets. To meet the needs of her customers and to earn income, she requests a loan to order baskets from other weavers to sell.

loans.use: To order baskets from other weavers to sell to her customers

loans.name: Carlos Alberto

texts.es: Carlos Alberto F. T. de 50 años de edad, reside en Ciudad Arce en el departamento de La Libertad, vive junto a su esposa y cuatro hijos los cuales se dedican a estudiar. Carlos posee una panadería desde hace 10 años, negocio el cual es atendido sobre todo por su esposa, así mismo él trabaja como agricultor y hace viajes a personas particulares ya que posee un pick up. Carlos solícita un préstamo a través del cual pueda comprar maíz y frijoles para realizar la siembra, así mismo comprar materia prima para la elaboración del pan, el cual lo comercializa el la zona en la cual él vive. Carlos es un hombre muy trabajador, el cual junto a su esposa se esfuerzan de diferentes maneras para poder brindarles una vida mejor a sus cuatro hijos, trabajan muy duro pero obtienen su recompensa al observar que sus hijos cuentan con todo lo básico para seguir adelante y poder seguir con sus estudios.
texts.en:
Carlos Alberto F. T. is 50 years old, lives in Arce City in the La Libertad district. He lives with his wife and four children, who are all studying. Carlos has owned a bakery for 10 years, a business which is mostly run by his wife. He, himself, works as a farmer and he uses his pick-up to work as a private driver. Carlos is seeking this loan in order to be able to buy corn and beans for planting and at the same time buy ingredients for bread, which he sells in the area where he lives. Carlos is a very hard-working man, and he, together with his wife, make an effort in many ways to be able to provide a better life for his four children. They work very hard but their reward is the recognition that their children can count on having all the basics in order to prosper and to be able to continue their studies.

Translated from Spanish by Julia Kastner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of rice and beans and ingredients for bread for his bakery.

location.town: Ciudad Arce en el departamento de La Libertad

loans.name: Ana Gladys

texts.es: Ana Gladys R. T. de 51 reside en Santa Ana junto a su hija. Ana posee una venta de frutas y verduras la cual esta ubicada cerca de la terminal de buses de Metapán, razón por la cual cuenta con muchos clientes, los cuales cuando van a abordar el bus, le compran su producto. Ana Gladys solícita un préstamo para poder comprar más fruta, ya que para esta temporada navideña se vende mucho sobre todo las uvas y manzanas. Ella es una persona muy trabajadora la cual llega a su puesto de ventas a las seis de la mañana y lo cierra a las seis treinta de la tarde, Ana Gladys es una persona la cual demuestra su deseo de seguir adelante y de ir mejorando día con día.
texts.en:
Ana Gladys R. T. is 51 years old and lives in Santa Ana with her daughter. Ana owns a fruit and vegetable store, which is located near the Metapán bus terminal. Because of her location, she has many clients, because when people are going to board a bus they buy her products. Ana Gladys is seeking a loan to be able to buy more fruit, because right now, at Christmas time, a lot of fruit, especially grapes and apples, sell very well. She is a very hard-working person, arriving at her stand at six in the morning and closing it at six thirty in the evening. Ana Gladys is the kind of person who truly demonstrates the desire to prosper and to continue, day by day, to improve her quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Julia Kastner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fruit

loans.name: Marta Alicia

texts.es: Marta Alicia M. D. H. D. 38 años D. edad, resiD. en el departamento D. La Paz, vive junto a su esposo y tres hijos menores D. edad. Ella posee una tienda D. productos perecederos, el cual ha ido mejorando con el tiempo gracias a préstamos anteriores. A pesar D. esto Marta es una mujer muy visionaría la cual desea tener su negocio mucho más surtido el cual le brinD. mayores ganancias y D. esta manera junto a su esposo darle una mejor vida a sus tres hijos los cuales se dedican a estudiar. Marta solícita un préstamo para poder comprar productos como jugos, golosinas, detergentes, entre otros más y así poder incrementar sus margenes D. ventas y tener una vida mejor junto a su familia.
texts.en:
Marta Alicia M. D. H. is 38 years old; she lives in the department of La Paz with her husband and her 3 young children. She has a store stocked with perishable products, which has been improving with time thanks to previous loans. In spite of this, Marta is a very visionary woman who wishes to have a business with a greater selection of products in order to make bigger profits. This way, together with her husband, they can give their 3 children a better quality of life, so they can focus on studying. Marta requests a loan to buy products like juices, candy, detergent and other things. With this, she can increase her sales margin and she can have a better life for her family.

Translated from Spanish by Lauren Jackson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy perishable products

loans.name: María Adela

texts.es: María Adela O. D. D. D. 43 años D. edad, resiD. en Olocuilta en el departamento D. La Paz. Vive junto a su esposo y tres hijos menores D. edad. Ella posee un molino en su casa, así mismo una tienda D. productos perecederos. María solícita un préstamo para poder comprar mas productos para la tienda, ya que este negocio es muy rentable en el lugar que vive, debido a que ella dependa en gran parte D. dicho negocio, tiene el deseo D. surtirlo y así mejorar las ventas, todo con el fin D. que su familia se vea beneficiada.
texts.en:
María Adela is 43 years old and resides in Olocuilta, in the Department of La Paz. She lives with her husband and 3 minor children.

María has a grinding mill in her house and a store with perishable products. She is soliciting a loan to buy more products for the store, since this business is very profitable there where she lives. She depends a great deal on the business, and wishes to keep it supplied and increase sales. This is so that her family may benefit.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: TO BUY PRODUCTS FOR HER STORE

location.town: Olocuilta en el departamento de San Salvador

loans.name: Gloria Marina

texts.es: Gloria Marina L. T. de 24 años de edad, reside en San Pedro Perulapán en el departamento de Cuscatlán. Vive junto a su compañero de vida y sus dos hijos de 8 y 5 años de edad. Gloria posee una venta de frutas en el mercado de Cojutepeque, dicho negocio lo posee desde hace ocho años. Gloria es una mujer muy esforzada, la cual trabaja muy duro por ayudarle a su esposo con los gastos del hogar. Es por esto que ella solícita un préstamo a través del cual pueda comprar más frutas, ya que este es un producto el cual se vende muy rápido y genera muy buenas ganancias.
texts.en:
Gloria Marina Lopez T., who is 24 years old, lives in San Pedro Perulapán in the town of Cuscatlan. She lives with her life partner and two sons who are 8 and 5 years of age. Gloria sells fruits in the Cojutepeque market, and says that she has had the business for eight years. Gloria is a very brave woman, who works hard to help her husband with household expenses. That's why she applied for a loan through which to buy more fruit, as this is a product that sells very quickly and generates very good profits.

Translated from Spanish by Zal Bilimoria, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fruits for sale

location.town: San Pedro Perulapán, departamento de Cuscatlán

loans.name: Sun

texts.en:
To earn a living, Sun T. sells baskets that she weaves. She sells her finished products to buyers who come directly to her house. She makes many sets of baskets before selling out. Another source of family income comes from her husband’s taxi-driving job. Sun has five kids; three are married and two are single. One of her sons is employed.

Recently, Sun ran out of the raw materials needed for weaving her baskets, and so she hopes to acquire more. That is why she decided to seek a loan through Kiva for buying materials for her basket-weaving business.

loans.use: To buy materials for her weaving basket business

loans.name: Feliciana Francisca

texts.es: Feliciana Francisca S. D. S. D. 38 años, resiD. en Izalco en el departamento D. Sonsonate. Vive junto a su esposo el cual trabaja como jornalero y a sus cinco hijos todos menores D. 12 años.  Feliciana posee una pequeña venta D. pollo y verduras ubicada en la calle principal D. Izalco, lugar el cual es muy transitado. Ella solicita un préstamo para poder comprar más pollo, ya que desea poder hacer crecer su negocio para poder brindarle una mejor ayuda a su esposo, el cual realiza un trabajo muy pesado el cuál no es muy bien pagado. Es por esto que Feliciana desea surtir su venta y poder incrementar sus ganancias, para poder brindarles todo lo necesario a sus cinco hijos.
texts.en:
Francisca Feliciana S. D. S. is 38 years old and resides in Izalco in the province of Sonsonate. She lives with her husband who works as a laborer and their five children, all of whom are under 12 years of age. Feliciana has a small business of selling chicken and vegetables, located in the main street of Izalco, which is a very busy place. She is requesting a loan to buy more chicken as she wishes to grow her business in order to proviD. better assistance to her husband, since his work is very difficult and is not well paid. This is why Feliciana wishes to fulfill sales and increase profits, which is necessary to proviD. for their five children.

Translated from Spanish by Zal Bilimoria, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase chickens for sale

loans.name: María Cristina

texts.es: María Cristina A. de 45 años de edad, reside en el departamento de Cuscatlán, junto a su hijo y una hermana. Ella posee una venta de ropa para niños y niñas, cada día María sale a las calles a ofrecer su producto, en muchas ocasiones visitas a clientes en sus propios hogares, en otras ocasiones grita por las calles ofreciendo la ropa. María es una mujer muy trabajadora la cual refleja el deseo por seguir adelante, es por esto que solícita un préstamo a través del cual pueda comprar más ropa e incrementar las ventas.
texts.en:
María Cristina is 45 years old and lives in the Department of Cuscatlán with her son and a sister.

She has a business selling clothes for boys and girls. Each day María heads for the streets to offer her products. She often visits customers in their own homes; on other occasions she walks the streets calling out her offer of clothes for sale.

María is a very hard-working woman, reflected in her desire to forge ahead. For this reason, she is soliciting a loan to buy more clothes and increase sales.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: TO BUY CLOTHES TO SELL

loans.name: Julio

texts.es: Julio H. P. de 41 años de edad, reside en San Martín, departamento de San Salvador, vive junto a su esposa y sus dos hijos de 11 y 8 años de edad. El tiene un taller de confecciones de prendas de vestir, negocio el cual es la única fuente de ingresos para sostener a su familia. Julio solícita un préstamo través del cual pueda comprar tela, hilo, botones y  todo tipo de productos para la elaboración y venta de ropa. Julio es un hombre muy honrado el cual anhela ver mejor a su familia y ver a sus hijos superarse, es por ello que tiene todas las intenciones de sacar adelante su negocio.
texts.en:
Julio Hernandez P. of 41 years of age, lives in San Martin, in the province of San Salvador. He lives with his wife and two sons, aged 11 and 8. He has a clothing shop business, which is the only source of income to support his family. Julio is requesting a loan through so he can buy fabric, thread, buttons and all kinds of products for making and selling clothes. Julio is a good man who yearns to improve the livelihood of his family and wants to see his children succeed. That is why he has every intention of succeeding in his own business.

Translated from Spanish by Zal Bilimoria, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase materials to make clothing for sale

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
Emily S. is from the village of Sinippil, Reina Mercedes. She is 54 years old and married with eight adult children. To make a living, Emily owns and operates a business raising chickens for sale. Emily has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately $8.75 a day from these activities.

In 2009, Emily joined the Kiva field partner, ASKI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation by engaging in business activities. Emily is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase baby chicks to raise and sell in the future. This will be her 1st loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase baby chicks to raise and sell in the future

loans.name: María Victoria

texts.es: María Victoria L. D. A. D. 53 años D. edad, resiD. en San Martín en el departamento D. San Salvador, vive junto a su esposo D. 67 años D. edad y tres nietos menores D. 9 años. María compra y venD. ropa para niños y adultos D. todas las edades, trabajo el cual tiene 15 años D. realizarlo. Ella comercializa la ropa D. manera ambulante, lo cual ella lo logra ver como una ventaja, ya que pueD. abarcar varias zonas D. San Martín y D. esta manera pueD. vender un poco más. María solícita un préstamo a través del cual pueda comprar más ropa y D. esta manera contar con mayor variedad D. prendas para ofrecer a sus clientes.
texts.en:
María Victoria is 53 years old, and lives in San Martín in the department of San Salvador. She lives with her husband who is 67 years old, and three grandchildren who are less than 9 years old. Maria buys and sells clothing for children and adults of all ages, work that she has been doing for 15 years. She markets the clothing as a street vendor, which she sees as an advantage, since she is able to cover several areas of San Martin, and this way she can sell a little more. Maria is requesting a loan through which she will be able to buy more clothes and this way count on a greater variety of clothing to offer her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Amy McGinty, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothing

loans.name: Daniel Isaías

texts.es: Daniel Isaías G. de 42 años redice en Colón en el departamento de La libertad, vive junto a su esposa y cinco hijas, de las cuales las dos mayores junto a su madre colaboran en el negocio de su padre. Daniel posee una panadería en la cual se encarga de elaborar y repartir el pan a sus diferentes clientes. Daniel solícita un préstamo a través del cual pueda comprar materia prima para la elaboración del pan, ya que desea aumentar su producción, beneficio el cual se vea reflejado en el bienestar de su extensa familia.
texts.en:
Daniel Isaías G. is 42 years old, and lives in Colón in the department of La Libertad. He lives with his wife and five children. The two oldest children, together with their mother, contribute to their father's business. Daniel owns a bakery, where he is in charge of making and delivering the bread to his different customers. Daniel is requesting a loan through which he will be able to buy raw materials for the baking of bread, since he wishes to increase his production, a benefit which will be reflected in the well-being of his extended family.

Translated from Spanish by Amy McGinty, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy raw materials

loans.name: Luis Larin

texts.es: Luis Larin S. de 55 años de edad, reside en el departamento de La libertad, junto a su esposa la cual trabaja como comerciante y su hija de 13 años de edad. El posee una tienda en la cual comercializa productos de primera necesidad, debido a que su tienda en la actualidad cuenta con muy pocos productos, las ganancias no son muy buenas. Es por esta razón que Luis solícita un préstamo a través del cual pueda comprar más productos como cereales, detergentes, entre otros más y de esta manera surtir la tienda y poder obtener mayores ganancias.
texts.en:
Luis Larin S. is 55 years old and lives in the department of La Libertad with his wife, who works as a shopkeeper, and his 13 year old daughter. He owns a shop where he markets basic necessities. Because his store currently has very few products, the profits are not very good. It is for this reason that Luis is requesting a loan, through which he will be able to buy more products, such as cereals, detergents, and other products to supply the store and to be able to obtain higher profits.

Translated from Spanish by Amy McGinty, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy basic necessity products

loans.name: Teresa De Jesús

texts.es: Teresa de Jesús G. de 63 años de edad, reside en el departamento de La Paz. Ella tiene  un solo hijo el cual cuenta con su propia familia. La señora Teresa posee una venta de ropa para niños y adultos, su negocio esta ubicado frente a la Alcaldía Municipal de La Paz, lo cual es una ventaja ya que es un lugar muy transitado. Teresa solícita un préstamo a través del cual pueda comprar más ropa, ya que a pesar que ella es una persona considerada de la tercera edad, es una mujer muy llena de energía la cual trabaja arduamente para llevar el alimento a su mesa.
texts.en:
Teresa de Jesús G. of 63 years of age, resides in the town of La Paz. She has one son who has his own family. Mrs. Teresa sells clothing for children and adults, and her business is located opposite of the La Paz City Hall, which is an advantage since it is a very busy place. Teresa is requesting a loan through so that she can buy more clothes. Although she is an elderly person, she is a very energetic woman who works hard to bring food to her table.

Translated from Spanish by Zal Bilimoria, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase new clothes for sale

loans.name: Carolina

texts.en:
Carolina O. is from the village of Quirino, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 49 years old and single with two adopted school-aged children. To make a living, Carolina owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Carolina has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $95 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Carolina joined the Kiva field partner, ASKI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation by engaging in business activities. Carolina is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her first loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Skilled in cooking and food processing, this is the hobby of Mrs. Helen R., 40 years of age and a resident of Labuyo, Tangub City. She is married to Maximino R. Jr., a government employee. They are blessed with four children, all of whom are now of school-age.

Helen started her carinderia (eatery) ten years ago with an initial capital of only P800. She was able to sustain the business even when we experienced economic crises in the country.

Helen joined Paglaum MPC a year ago because she is very much interested in our products and services and for our being one of the most outstanding cooperatives in Northern Mindanao, and the awarded coop for being “Most Outstanding Cooperative in the Philippines” during the search for the COOP-LGU Partnership Award 2006.

With a good credit record and with capacity, she was able to obtain multiple loans. Now she is given the privilege of obtaining a loan of P8,000 to add the capital of her carinderia and to buy and sell hotdogs and milk powder.

Helen’s only dream in life is to be able to support her children especially in their education.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her carinderia and to buy hotdogs and powdered milk to sell

loans.name: Rudy

texts.en:
Rudy C. is from the village of Quirino, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 40 years old and single. To make a living, Rudy sells Avon and Natasha cosmetics products. He has been engaged in this business for over three years and earns approximately $138 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Rudy joined the Kiva field partner, ASKI, to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation by engaging in business activities. Rudy is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be his 1st loan  from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his general living conditions. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Moriay

texts.en:
Moriay R. is currently in the business of selling fresh vegetables and groundnut paste and is requesting a loan to purchase bags of charcoal to sell.  Moriay is 30 years old and married. Her husband is a potter. She has three children and they all go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase bags of charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Elvira

texts.en:
Elvira L. lives in Hacienda Malisbog 4, Brgy E Lopez, Silay City, Negros Occidental. She is 45 years old. Her husband, Rogelio, works as a tricycle driver within their village and around Silay City. She has two children who are presently attending school. Her dreams in life are to help her husband generate additional income for the family, so that her children can finish their studies. She also wants to improve her family's living conditions.

In 1998 Elvira joined the Kiva field partner, NWTF-Project Dungganon, to have capital to invest in a business. She used her loan for a tricycle as the source of their income. She also invested in the buying and selling of scrap, like empty bottles, scrap iron, plastics and many other things that can be useful and acceptable to sell. As she continued her loans with NWTF, her business grew and earned additional income for the family. She would get a minimum income of $77 a month, which she used for her family.

Previously, Elvira borrowed 19,500 PHP as additional capital for her scrap business and it was paid back on a weekly basis, and fully paid within her loan term without any delay. Because of her good credit performance, she was able to access a bigger loan. She recently borrowed 25,000 PHP for her 18th cycle loan, to use as additional capital for her scrap business. The income will be used for the education of her children and for her business.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional capital for her scrap business

loans.name: Ramona

texts.en:
Ramona C. lives in Paraiso 2, Brgy Taloc, Bago City, Negros Occidental. She is 62 years old. Her husband, Leonardo, helps her in managing their business. The couple is blessed with seven children and twelve grandchildren. Ramona helps send her grandchildren to school. She would like some of her children to finish with their studies so they can help improve the business and work together as a family to make it grow.

Ramona used to work in the rice field with her husband. Then she got into pig-fattening as additional income for the family, but it wasn't enough.

Because she needed capital to invest in a general store, Ramona joined the Kiva field partner, NWTF-Project Dungganon, in 2005. She was very happy because the family income increased because of her new business. Although she manages her general store business as well as the pig-fattening business, she still does part-time work in the rice field. With her businesses, she has earned a minimum of about $72 a month. Ramona saves most of her income for education and for household expenses.

She borrowed 19,000 PHP in a previous loan to use as additional capital for her general store. That amount was fully paid within her loan term without any interest. Now, Ramona will be borrowing 19,500 PHP for her 10th cycle loan, to be used as additional capital for her general store and for repairs to her pig pens.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through "Project Dungganon" (a Hiligaynon word that means "Honorable"). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them "Dungganon" - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

Pekina is 30 years old and married. Her husband is a driver. She has five children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house in her settlement.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. loans.name: Ulysses

texts.en:
Ulysses H. is from the village of Quirino, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 33 years old. Ulysses is married and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, he owns and operates a business venture in the services sector. While not the only means of generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing transportation services to local community members. Ulysses has been engaged in his motorcycle transport business for over two years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Ulysses joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ulysses is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Ulysses from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of his family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fishermen and small business entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Ranulfa

texts.en:
Mrs. Ranulfa A., 49, is married and a resident of Migpangi, Bonifacio, Misamis Occidental. Her husband Jesus A. is a driver is with an average net income of 3,000 Philippine pesos (about $65 US).  That amount is not sufficient to support their big family with 4 dependents who are in high school and elementary school. 

To add their family income, they decided to start using a pump boat for the transport of passengers going to Kapatagan, Lanao del Norte and other parts of Lanao. Now the couple is earning an average net income of not less than 5,000 pesos (about $108 US) a month.  

Mrs. A. joined PAGLAUM MPC in July 2008 because she is very much interested in our products and services. She is also interested in PAGLAUM MPC for being one of the most outstanding cooperatives in Northern Mindanao: we were named Most Outstanding Cooperative in the Philippines during the search for the COOP-LGU Partnership Award 2006. 

With the willingness to pay shown to our cooperative, she was given the opportunity to request a loan of 7,000 pesos to finance the overhaul and reconditioning of the pump boat engine and the repair of the boat. The couple is hoping that someday they can purchase a new pump boat engine and another boat to be used for the business.

loans.use: For repair of boat and its engine

loans.name: Cherish's Group

texts.en:
Cherish C., from the village of Roxas, is the 42-year-old leader of a 13-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Rang-ayan.

Cherish, the married mother of five school-aged children, prepares and sells cooked food for daily meals. Engaged in her business for over 10 years, she earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Cherish joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having fully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI that was used to purchase additional products to sell, Cherish is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her enterprise.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mainly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia P. is a 53-year-old widow living with her children in Pangarap (Dream) Village, Caloocan City.

Virginia has a general store located in her residence. She also maintains coin-operated video-game consoles. Virginia says she has coped and moved on from the pain of losing her husband and now enjoys attending her business. She now earns more than 30,000 Philippine pesos.  

Virginia joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) credit cooperative in 2005. She has been active in inviting other women in her community to her group. She has just finished repaying her previous loan with the cooperative. Now, for her 13th loan, she has applied for a fresh loan in the amount of P14,000 as additional capital for her business. She dreams of having a larger grocery store someday.  

<b>About CCT<b/>

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.name: Puth

texts.en: Puth S., 38, is a married man and the father of four school-aged children, one of whom is married. To earn a living, Puth S. built a pigpen next to his house where he raises many pigs for slaughter. He sells all his mature pigs to buyers four months after he begins raising them. His wife is a vegetable seller and is also a homemaker who cooks delicious meals for the family. Because raising pigs is a profitable business for this family, Puth S. is applying for a loan to buy more piglets to feed.

loans.use: To buy more piglets to feed

loans.name: Matilde

texts.en:
This is Matilde F., mother of four children, one of whom is still in college; the first three are now working. She is married to Cezar, 57, a fish vendor. They live in Baranggay Tala, Caloocan City.

Matilde runs a small sari-sari (variety) store. Along with basic household necessities, she also sells fresh fish and cooked food. All her businesses gives her a net income of P 4,500 a month. She is saving her profit to build up funds for the renovation of their house.

She is now on her tenth loan with the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative. She has applied for a new loan in the amount of P 12,000 as additional capital for her business. She will buy more items to sell at her store.

She wants to see her general store become bigger than it is now. She also dreams of having her own market stall to sell her fresh fish.

loans.name: Virgie

texts.en:
This is Virgie B., a 42-year-old store owner from Executive Village, Dasmariñas, Cavite. She is also in the food business. She has five children; one is in college, two in high school, and two in grade school. Her husband drives a tricycle (local three-wheeled transport vehicle).

Virgie has been in business for ten years. She cooks and sells food while attending to her general store. She makes a net profit of more than to P30,000 per month which she uses to sustain the studies of her children.

She has just finished repaying a previous loan with the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative which qualifies her for a new loan so she applied for a new loan in the amount of P17,000. This would be her eight loan with CCT. She will use the loan proceeds to purchase additional merchandise for her store so she won’t need to come to the market so often. Virgie dreams of owning a bigger grocery store.

texts.en:
Ou T., 61, is a professional cleaner who started her work eight years ago. She currently does her work at the local hospital and earns a stable salary of US$ 70 each month. She was married, but her husband died of old age. She now has three children who are working in the garment industry.

Ou T. has faced difficulties with sanitation because her house doesn’t have a bathroom. Therefore, Ou T. is requesting a US$ 500 loan to be used to build a new bathroom for her family’s hygiene.

texts.en: Pradixes Baraza E. sells used clothes including shirts, T-shirts and trousers to repeat and walk-in customers from a stall in a market near Aga Khan hospital.  She has been in this business for four years, and her business challenge is the rainy season as her stall is the open air.  She is using the proceeds of KES 20,000 loan to buy bales of used shirts, T-shirts and trousers.  In the future, she wants to expand into a boutique, enroll her children  in a good school so that all have the best in their life.  Pradixes is married to a driver and  has three daughters.   She describes herself as hard-working.

loans.name: Lucena

texts.en:
Mrs. Lucena C. is a resident of Purok 6 Labuyo, Tangub City, 53 years of age, married to Mr. Olimpio C., a contractor. She has 5 children; 1 of them is still studying and the rest are already married. She is engaged in operating a sari-store which she newly opened in August 2009 with a starting capital of P 1,000 only. Now, she is earning an average net income of P2,000 a month.

Upon hearing the good news of PAGLAUM MPC as the one of the outstanding cooperatives of Northern Mindanao (awarded the Most Outstanding Cooperative in the Philippines during the search for COOP-LGU Partnership award in the year 2006), she unhesitatingly joined the coop. With her good record in the community and with the capacity to repay, she was given the privilege of accessing the amount of P 5,000 as her 1st loan to add to her capital for her existing sari-sari store. The future income from this loan will be used to meet their daily needs and for the educational expenses for her child who is studying. She is hoping that someday she will have a mini-grocery store in their place.
