loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
Imelda S. is from the village of Sinippil, Reina Mercedes, Isabela. She is 42 years old. Imelda is single and has 1 school-aged children. To make a living, Imelda is starting a service-based business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing manicure and pedicure services in the local community. Imelda is just starting this business.

In 2009, Imelda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Imelda is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide the service. This will be the first loan taken out by Imelda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her child.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Sok Y. is a 44-year-old farmer living in the best territory of Kampong Chhnang province, in Cambodia. She also depends on the income from her husband’s taxi-driving. Sok Y. has given birth to four children who are employed at various occupations.

Sok Y. hopes to generate extra income by using a loan from Kiva to order silk skirts in bulk from rural weavers. She will retail them to gain a profit.

loans.use: To order silk skirts in bulk from rural weavers

loans.name: Luz

texts.en:
Luz M. is from the village of Sinippil, Reina Mercedes, Isabela. She is 52 years old. Luz is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Luz owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Luz is just starting this business.

In 2009, Luz joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Luz is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Luz from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mirna

texts.en: Mirna is a 20-year-old single woman. She is living with her parents and five brothers and sisters. Mirna has been working as a tailor since 2007. Now, she is borrowing US$ 1,000 in order to buy a new sewing machine to satisfy her customers' needs.

loans.use: to buy a new sewing machine

loans.name: Letecia

texts.en:
A businesswoman living in Baybay, Bonifacio, Mis.Occ., Letecia P. is a recent member of the Micro-Finance Program PDPLP (Paglaum Development Program for Landless People). She is 42 years of age, married and has 5 children. One is helping her cover their daily expenditures.

The business Letecia has at present is one she has been in for 20 years, quite a long time! Through this business, she sent her children to school. Her husband is also managing their native wine production which makes a great help for their family. Her sari-sari store is really helping them, with a net profit of Php 4,000 a month. She is making another additional amount just to make her sari-sari store prosper which is the main purpose of her loan.

Being a member of the most outstanding cooperative in the Philippines in search of Coop- LGU Partnership Award 2006 is indeed a great help for her reputation. One thing for sure: her net profit is to save and make savings for the children in the near future.

loans.use: Additional capital for her existing sari-sari store

loans.name: Kudiratu

texts.en: Kudiratu is 45 years old, married and has three children. Her oldest child is 20 and her youngest is 13. Her husband is a commercial driver, and Kudiratu contibutes to the family income by selling colorful shoes and bags at retail prices to customers in Ibadan, Oyo state, Nigeria. She hopes to own a boutique in the future. This is the high season for sales and this loan will help her increase her income by allowing her to buy more shoes and bags to sell. She extends her sincerest thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy more shoes and bags to sell

loans.name: Zoulfikar

texts.en: Zoulfikar is single and lives at home with his six sibilings. He is a very hard worker, and in 2007 decided to open a bakery where he makes delicious breads and other products. He has applied for a loan for $1,200 to buy additional tools and appliances for his bakery.

loans.use: to buy additional tools and appliances

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
Emma C. lives in the village of Estrella, San Guillermo, Isabela. She is 32 years old, married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, she raises pigs for sale. She has been in this line of work for more than one year and earns about 1,500 PHP a month.

Earlier this year, Emma joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She is requesting a new loan for 4000 PHP to buy livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be Emma's first from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue made possible by this loan to supplement her family's income. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Folashade

texts.en: Folashade is a very focused, hard-working woman. She puts in long hours trying to keep her businesses sustainable. She is 36 years old, married and has three children. For the last four years, she has made a living selling building materials. She lives in Ibadan, Oyo State, Nigeria, and has applied for a loan for N80,000 to buy more building materials to sell and to expand her business. She extends sincerest thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To buy more building materials to sell

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
This is Lucia O., a 62-year-old woman who lives in Pasay City. She is married to Fernando, a local community peace-keeping volunteer.

Lucia started a coin-operated video games arcade last year that has proved to be very popular to many customers, especially children, and her days are now very busy. She earns more than PHP 15,000 in monthly profits from her business.  She is using this money to send her child to college.

Leticia considers her membership with the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative a heaven-sent blessing, and she mentions this frequently to friends and relatives. She has applied for a loan for PHP 12,000 to renovate her arcade, which was slightly damaged by recent typhoons. She will use the money to buy plywood panels and roofing materials.  

Soon, thanks to her hard work, Leticia expects her child to graduate from college and help the family escape from living in poverty. 

About CCT
The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response to poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: to renovate a video arcade center

loans.name: Fadel

texts.en:
Fadel has worked as a builder since 2005. He’s 23 years old and living with his parents. He helps his family to raise his three unemployed brothers who still go to school.

Today, Fadel is requesting $800 to buy a special wood support for his business.

loans.use: To buy a special wood support

loans.name: Tenjil

texts.en:
This micro-entrepreneur is a seaman’s wife named Mrs. Tenjil R.. She is 27 years of age and is a resident of Mantic, Tangub City. Unfortunately, the couple still has no child yet. They wish to have a baby someday to complete their family.

Even if she is receiving a monthly allotment from her husband and earning an income from her parcel of riceland, Tenjil still loves to engage in business because she doesn’t want to depend solely on her husband’s income. She opened her little sari-sari (variety) store a year ago. Now she is earning an average income from her store of P1,500 a month which contributes to her income.

Tenjil joined Paglaum MPC a year ago and is so thankful and indeed, feels it a great honor to be a member of the most outstanding cooperative in Northern Mindanao and the awarded coop for being “Most Outstanding Cooperative in the Philippines” during the search for the COOP-LGU Partnership Award 2006.

For her 2nd loan, Tenjil is applying for P35,000 to finance the cultivation and production of her parcel of riceland and to add to the capital of her sari-sari store.

loans.use: To finance the cultivation and production of her riceland and to use as additional capital for her sari-sari store

location.town: Mantic, Tangub City, Misamis Occidental, Mindanao

loans.name: Marcialyn

texts.en: Marcialyn C. is from the village of Estrella, San Guillermo, Isabela. She is 29 years old, is married, and has two school-aged children. Marcialyn owns and operates a direct-selling business providing personal use products in local community. She has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 1,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Marcialyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in other business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase chicken feed for the chickens she raises to sell. This loan will be her first from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase chicken feed

loans.name: Docas

texts.en:
Docas is 40 years old and married with four children. Her eldest child is 9 years old and her youngest child is 2. Her children are excelling in school. Her husband is a pastor and he also supports the home. She has a business center where she renders computer services, photocopies documents for her customers and sells stationery. With these combined businesses, she hopes to make more profits. 

She is requesting a loan of 50,000 Nigeria naira to purchase more stationery. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more stationery

loans.name: Jonalyn

texts.en:
Jonalyn C. is from the village of Estrella, San Guillermo, Isabela. She is 28 years old. Jonalyn is single. To make a living, Jonalyn runs a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Jonalyn is just starting this business.

In 2009, Jonalyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jonalyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 Philippine pesos, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Jonalyn from ASKI, a Kiva partner. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Adoracion

texts.en: This is Adoracion S., 44, from Pasay City. She is an itinerant vendor of anything that goes with the season. She buys and sells everything from candies and other food items to small toys for kids. She endures the daily strain of buying all her stuff from the commercial district and carrying it all by herself. Her inspiration for doing this hard work is her six children. She has two college students, another two in high school and one in grade school. She also sells electronic load credits for mobile phones. From all of this, she earns a monthly net income of close to 12,000 Philippine pesos, at least enough to make both ends meet along with her husband’s income. Her husband, Leonardo, 45, works as a personal driver. Adoracion joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) credit cooperative in 2004. She has just finished repaying her previous loan with the cooperative and has applied for a new loan in the amount of P17,000. This would be her 13th loan. She will use the funds to purchase more toy items in line with the holiday season. She also wishes to own a computer shop and an Internet cafe. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social-development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: Purchase toy items to sell

loans.name: Pepe Jun

texts.en:
Hog raising is the hobby of Mr. Pepe Jun V. who is 27 years of age, single, and a resident of Polao, Tangub City. He is also a skilled electronics technician specializing in appliances and other electronic equipment with an average net income of not less than P3,200 a month. He has been engaged in this kind of job for eight years already.

Pepe Jun joined Paglaum MPC because he wanted to be part of the organization that is considered as one of the most progressive cooperatives in Northern Mindanao and one that reaches out to rural communities. For the 3rd time, he is given the privilege of obtaining P25,000 to finance his hog-raising activity, especially in buying feed. The remaining amount will be used for the purchase of additional accessories for his electronics repair shop.

Pepe Jun’s future income will be used for his basic needs and for loan repayments. He is hoping that his piggery will prosper someday.

loans.use: To purchase hog feed and additional accessories for his electronics repair business

location.town: Polao, Tangub City, Misamis Occidental, Mindanao

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is 35 years old and is married with four children. Her eldest child is 16 years old and the youngest is 3 years old. Both children are schooling. Her husband is a commercial driver.

Florence sells crates of drinks at retail and wholesale prices to her customers. When her children are on holidays, they assist her with sales. She is requesting a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more crates of drinks to sell. This is the festive season and she hopes to meet the demands of her customers. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of drinks to sell

loans.name: Yolla

texts.en:
Yolla is a 20-year-old single woman. Eight years ago she decided to begin working early as a hairdresser to help her family with the household expenses. And in 2005, she opened her own beauty salon to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities.

Today, Yolla is requesting $1,000 to buy cosmetics products requested by her clients.

loans.use: To buy cosmetics products

loans.name: Long

texts.en: Long L., 44, a local farmer who has been growing rice since 1985, is married to Keo La, 45, who owns a machine that provides a battery-charging service for neighbors. This couple has been married for many years and is blessed with three school-aged children. Long L.’s husband has gained much income from his service, but unfortunately the machine often breaks down, thus affecting his income. To solve the problem, Long L. is requesting a loan to hire a mechanic to repair it.

loans.use: To hire a mechanic to repair the battery-charging machine

loans.name: Fatimo

texts.en:
Fatimo is 55 years old and is married with four children. Her youngest child is 12 years old. She lives in Ibadan, Oyo State, Nigeria.

Fatimo sells planks at retail prices to her customers and has been in this business for a long time. She uses her experience in the business to attract more customers to her business.

Fatimo is happy because the dry season is here and the demand for her planks will increase. She is requesting a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more planks to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more planks to sell

loans.name: Idowu

texts.en:
Idowu is 34 years old and is married with two children. She helps her husband to support the family.

Idowu sells phone rechargeable cards and pure water and has been in the business for the past four years. One of her greatest joys is the one-on-one interaction she is able to have with her customers.

With this loan of 170,000 NGN Idowu plans to increase and restock her rechargeable phone cards and water due to an increase in demand. With this business she hopes to increase her earnings in the long run and be able to provide better for her children's education.

Most of the challenges Idowu faces in her business are that the electricity supply is inconsistent, and that she needs it to cool her water. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more phone recharge cards and pure water to sell

loans.name: Vicky

texts.en:
Vicky G. is from Rizal, Santiago City. She is 41 years old, married, and has three school-aged children.

Vicky owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector managing a direct selling business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling cosmetics and apparel products of AVON,Natasha,MSE and Sundance. Vicky has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Vicky joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which she will used to purchase more items to sell. This loan will be her first loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 


About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more items to sell

loans.name: Heriknaz

texts.en:
Heriknaz A. lives in Yerevan with her husband, sister-in-law, and her school-age son. Heriknaz worked in a self-service store as a cashier, and then she worked in shoe factory. In 1991 Heriknaz and her husband left Armenia for Bulgaria where they managed their own shop. After 5 years they have returned home and Heriknaz has started her business renting a space at the trade fair. Her husband is now working at “Ashtarak milk” organization as a mechanic.

Heriknaz sells toys, including mechanical, musical, and educational toys. Now she is requesting a loan of US$ 900 to buy a lot of toys for her shop in view of the New Year's holidays. With the future income Heriknaz hopes to be able to have mixed products in her shop.

loans.use: To buy a lot of toys for her shop

loans.name: Liezell

texts.en:
Liezell R. is from the village of Estrella, San Guillermo, Isabela. She is 35 years old. Liezell is married and has 3 children. To make a living, Liezell owns & operates a business venture in motorcycle transport. The main source of income for the business comes from providing motorcycle transport in the local community. Liezell has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 150 Php daily for these activities.

In 2009, Liezell joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in another business activities. Due to lack of financial assistance for the education of her children, Liezell is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase some vegetables to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Liezell from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Gaberi

texts.en: Gaberi is a member of LAPO microfinance and he is excited to take out a Kiva loan. He will use this loan to invest in a business selling tyres which he will buy in bulk to get a better price. He is 27 years old, married with a child. He sells tyres to meet the need of his family.  He lives in Ibadan, Oyo state, Nigeria. His wife sells clothes and they both contribute to supporting the family. The challenge he faces in his tyre business is capital.  He is requesting the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more tyres to sell.  He says thank you to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more tyres to sell

loans.name: Kazeem

texts.en: Kazeem is 36 years old, married with 3 children; his youngest child is 3 years old. Kazeem’s children are schooling. His wife sells sarongs to support the home. He is a tailor and he makes lovely Nigerian designs for his customers. His greatest joy in his business is the one-on-one interaction that he has with his customers. He is requesting the loan amount of 50,000 NGN to purchase more tailoring materials to sew more clothes for his customers. This is the high season for his tailoring skills and he hopes to make more profits during this season. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Mary Ann M. is from the village of Estrella, San Guillermo, Isabela. She is 26 years old. Mary Ann is married and has 2 young children. To make a living, Mary Ann owns & operates a business in direct selling of cosmetics and personal products and at the same time providing transportation services in the community. The main sources of income for the business comes from her direct selling and tricycle transportation services to local community members. Mary Ann has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 1000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Mary Ann joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mary Ann is requesting a loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell in the local community. This will be the first loan taken out by Mary Ann from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Martina Sirri

texts.en:
Martina Sirri is married with seven children living in Musang, Mankong, Cameroon. Martina and her entire family are currently living in a house with one room. She has had to overcome some challenges in her life such as inadequate funds to pay her children's school fees, ill health, and the recent death of close relatives.

Martina has been eking out a living through the sale of chopped wood and the sale of corn and groundnuts. She plans to invest this loan in buying wood, corn, and groundnuts. This will be Martina's forth loan from GHAPE. She has been a member since 2005. To date, she has been quite successful in her business projects which can be credited to the location of her business and her reasonable prices. Also, her experience has led to good profits from her business.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Buying wood, corn and groundnuts

loans.name: Gloria

Gloria D. is from the village of Estrella, San Guillermo, Isabela. She is 40 years old. Gloria is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Gloria owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Gloria has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately PHP 300 daily for these activities.

In 2009, Gloria joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Rosalinda G., 59 years old, like many women entrepreneurs in the Philippines, earns money from buyng and selling cosmetic items and apparel from prominent direct-sales companies (Avon, Sundance, Natasha, Marikina Shoe Exchange, etc.) which is a tried and tested alternative source of income for housewives.

Rosalinda’s family lives in Dasmariñas, Cavite. Her husband Edito, 64, is now receiving his pension as a retired employee. They live with their grandchildren. She enjoys her business a lot, going to her friends on a house-to-house basis to sell her items. She earns P7,000 a month and even more during the holiday season.

She has been with the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative since 2005. The loans provided by the cooperative helped her to pay for cosmetic items from the dealers in cash (otherwise she must pay for them on a consignment basis) so she could take advantage of large discounts and rebates which she also infuses back into her business. Currently, she's applying for a P12,000 loan from CCT to get more cosmetic items from her dealer in anticipation of the upcoming Christmas season.

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: purchase more cosmetics for resale

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en: Mariam is a 46-year-old widow with 2 unemployed children. She has been working in bag production since 2007 and has 7 years of experience in this field. Today, Mariam is requesting to borrow US$ 800 to purchase necessary production supplies for her work.

loans.use: purchase necessary supplies

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen S. is from the village of Estrella, San Guillermo, Isabela. She is 43 years old. Helen is married and has 3 adult children. Helen owns & operates a business raising pigs for sale. Helen has been engaged in her business for over 23 years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Helen joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to engage in business activities. Helen is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future. This will be the first loan taken out by Helen from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients make their living from farming, fishing and small entrepreneurial businesses.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future.

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en:
This is Carmelita C., 44, who lives and does business in Dasmariñas, Cavite. She is a multi-tasking entrepreneur, attending to an array of business activities.  She has been in business for fifteen years. Her husband, Ruperto, 49, is a salesman. They have two children who are both in grade school.

Carmelita owns a general store, which has been around for fifteen years. In addition, she buys and sells fresh pork meat and dressed chicken. Her neighbors order from her. She buys items from the slaughterhouse in large amounts and delivers to her customers. She makes it a point to ensure that the orders be served as promised, although she sometimes finds it difficult to recover unpaid debts from some customers. She also sells RTW (ready-to-wear) clothing.  Her most recent business venture is bicycle rental. From all these activities, she earns more than PHP 32, 000 in monthly profits. She banks most of her income for future use, especially for her children’s education.

Her membership with the (CCT) Credit Cooperative has brought her a lot of blessings in life and in business. In anticipation of the upcoming holiday season, she has been receiving a lot of new orders for hog meat and chicken. To answer for her commitments, she will need additional capital. She has applied for a new loan with the cooperative in the amount of PHP 31, 000.  This will be her sixth loan cycle with CCT. 

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: Additional capital for meat orders.

loans.name: Stella

texts.en: Stella is a focused hard worker. She is 30 years old, married, and has 3 children. She sells clothes and has been in the business for the past 6 years. She would like to get a loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase a variety of clothing items and will significantly expand her clothing trade. Stella believes that having an assortment of women's outerwear that is both practical and good quality will increase her sales. She is a member of LAPO and has a good repayment report. She says thank you to all kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Emelita

texts.en:
Emelita Q. is from the city of Linao East Tuguegarao City. She is 39 years old. Emelita is still single. To make a living, Emelita owns & operates a general store. where she sells a variety of different products in the local community. Emelita has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

Emelita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to engage in business activities. Emelita is requesting a new loan of 30000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the second loan taken out by Emelita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Elvira

texts.en:
Mrs. Elvira S. is 30 years of age and is a resident of Guinalaban, Tangub City. She is married to Ricky S. who is a merchandiser for Juanita Enterprise with an average salary of not less than P6,180 per month. The couple is blessed with two children who are now of school age.

In order to help her husband, Elvira decided to engage in a sari-sari (variety) store. For a period of two years to the present day she was able to sustain the business and earn an average net income of not less than P5,000 per month.

Elvira joined Paglaum MPC just this year because she is very much interested in our products and services and for our being one of the most outstanding cooperatives in Northern Mindanao, and the awarded coop for being “Most Outstanding Cooperative in the Philippines” during the search for the COOP-LGU Partnership Award 2006. 

Being on her first loan, Elvira was given the privilege of obtaining P5,000 to add to the capital of her sari-sari store. The future income from this loan will be used for her daily needs, for repayments to Paglaum MPC, and for savings.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional stock of bulk seeds for her veterinary shop.

loans.name: Riza

texts.en:
Riza R., 25 years old, hails from a farming family in Balubad, Silang, Cavite. She is married to Regie, 24, a factory worker. Riza grows pineapples in a family-owned farm lot. Since farming is a seasonal source of income, Riza also sells dried fish to her neighbors. She earns close to PHP 3,000 a month.  
 
Riza is now on her sixth loan cycle with the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative. She enjoys the camaraderie of the women entrepreneurs. She is applying for a new loan in the amount of PHP 9,000, which she will use to fund the next pineapple crop season. She will purchase fertilizers and pesticides.  

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase of fertilizers and pesticides.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients for making snacks.

loans.name: Keji

texts.en:
Keji M. is currently in the business of selling eggs and used clothes in the market. She is requesting a loan to purchase bags of charcoal for sell.  Keji is 25 years old and is married. Her husband is a doctor. She has 2 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a permanent house for settlement.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase bags of charcoal for sale.

loans.name: Funke

texts.en: Funke is 35 years old, married, and has 3 children. Her eldest child is 16 years old and the youngest is 11 years old. She sells frozen foods such as turkey, chicken and beef to make a living in Ibadan, Oyo state, Nigeria. Her greatest joy is the festive season. She is happy because her sales and profits will increase. She is requesting a loan in the amount of 50,000 NGN to purchase more frozen foods to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more frozen food to sell.

loans.name: Nji Cristina

texts.en:
Nji Cristina is a married mother of six children.  

Cristina and her entire family currently live in Mile 90 Nsogwa, Cameroon. Cristina shares that her primary difficulties in life have been to find funding to pay for her children's school fees.  She is also dealing with a minor illness and the death of relative. Cristina has found these complications make daily life somewhat difficult, but she also finds ways to contribute to her community. Cristina shares that she is active in her support of education within her neighborhood and provides a healthy means of nourishment by selling nutritious food in her convenience store.       

With a loan from GHAPE she would like to purchase firewood, groundnuts, rice, beans, soap and oil in order to expand her inventory and her profits.  She is hoping to use her profits to purchase livestock and reinvest into her business.  

As a member since 2005, Christina has already repaid four loans from GHAPE. She has been quite successful in the past and hopes to continue getting larger and larger loans with which to grow her store.  

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Purchase of food inventory to be sold through her store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional stock in bulk for her grocery.

loans.name: Adenike

texts.en:
Adenike is 34 years old and is married with three children. She lives in Ibadan, Oyo State, Nigeria.

Adenike sells clothes and drinks to her customers. With the combined businesses, she helps the husband to support the family's basic needs and other necessities.

With the loan of N50,000, Adenike plans to expand her clothes and drinks business, which is now booming. With this kind of business she hopes to increase her earnings in the long run and be able to better provide for her children's education.

Adenike also owns a hairdressing business offering hairstyling services in a location that is very favorable for most of her customers. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes and drinks to sell

loans.name: Mah-E-Now Group

texts.en:
The pictured group is Mah-e-Now which is made up of five female members. Hasema is the group leader. She is 48 and married with 5 children. She weaves different kinds of carpets and she needs a loan to buy good quality materials to grow her business. Wahida is a good seamstress and she sews kids clothes in her house. Many of her neighbors like her work and buy their children's clothes from her. She is seeking a loan to buy a new machine for her business. Sara jan sells embroidery, which is very popular in Afghanistan. She wants money to buy supplies for her business. Mariza wants a loan for her husband who has a small cosmetics shop. He would like to buy more inventory for his shop. The last member of the group is Fatana who would like to receive a loan for her brother who has a clothing shop. She is confident that her brother's business will expand quickly.

Together they have requested a group loan of 50000 Afghani and would like to thank Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy carpet-weaving materials

loans.name: Ghena

texts.en: Ghena is a 28-year-old single woman. She has owned a roasting business since 2004. She serves the neighboring villages. Today, Ghena is requesting to borrow $1,200 to increase her purchases in order to augment her sales and make a good income.

loans.use: Increasing purchases

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional stock in bulk

loans.name: Majed

texts.en:
Majed is a 30-year-old married man. He has owned a barber shop in his town since 2004 and has eighteen years of experience in this field.

Today, Majed is asking to borrow $1,200 to renovate his shop and to add new decor in order to attract more clients and increase his income.

loans.use: To renovate his shop and add new decor

loans.name: Anna

texts.en:
Anna is 35 years old and is married with four children. She lives in Ibadan, Oyo State, Nigeria. Her husband sells shoes and they both contribute to supporting the family.

Anna owns a restaurant where she sells cooked foods in a location that is very favorable for most of her customers. She plans to expand her food business by adding the sale of drinks and water since there is high demand for them.

Anna is requesting a loan of N50,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She say thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs and drinks to sell

loans.name: Forti Evelyn

texts.en:
Forti Evelyn is a married mother of three small children. She lives in Mile 90 Nsogwa, Cameroon.

Evelyn and her entire family are living in a house with five rooms. Evelyn shares that some of her everyday challenges include the death of her first son and her poor health.  These afflictions have been difficult for her from an emotional and financial perspective.  To deal with her financial need, Evelyn currently has a small food stand in a local market through which she sells food and everyday items.  

With this loan, Evelyn hopes to invest in additional inventory for her store.  She will specifically be purchasing rice, corn, groundnuts, beans, soap, and oil.

Evelyn has been with GHAPE since 2007 and has successfully repaid two individual loans.  Investing in her food stand has done well for her in the past and she is confident of continued success because of her experience and reasonable prices.  

Evelyn hopes to spend part of the profits from this loan on health care for her children.  She would like to P. them with some preventative treatment to avoid future illnesses.  

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: The purchase of rice, corn, beans, soap, oil and groundnuts for resale

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en: Josefina Y. is a 51-year-old woman entrepreneur from Balubad, Silang, Cavite. Her husband, Ladislao, 57, is the village’s local chieftain. Josefina owns a general store and it has been around for the last twenty years. She earns up to P11,000 per month in net income and uses her profits to support her children. Josefina is now on her sixteenth loan with the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative and has recently applied for a new loan of P10,000. She will use the funds to purchase more items to sell at her general store. Josefina dreams of improving her general store so that it becomes a big grocery store someday. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase more items to sell at her store

loans.name: Aïchatou Elise

texts.fr: D. Aïchatou Elise est née en 1970 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à FOLY Narcisse, Aïchatou Elise est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Aïchatou Elise a un autre enfant à charge, en plus de ses enfants. Aïchatou Elise vit depuis trois ans à Cococodji, non loin de Cotonou, avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Aïchatou Elise a arrêté l'école au cours secondaire, et a appris la coiffure. Depuis près de 8 ans, Aïchatou Elise exerce ce métier. Aïchatou Elise vend également des produits cosmétiques et des mèches dans son atelier de coiffure à Cococodji. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et à Lomé au Togo, pays voisin du Bénin, que Aïchatou Elise s'approvisionne. Aïchatou Elise a obtenu une fois de crédit à ALIDé, crédit qui a été bien remboursé. En vue d'agrandir davantage son activité afin de satisfaire plus sa clientèle, Aïchatou Elise sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Aïchatou Elise D. was born in 1970 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. Married to Narcisse Foly, Aïchatou Elise is the mother of three children, all of whom are in school. Aïchatou Elise takes care of another child in addition to her own children. For three years, Aïchatou Elise has lived in Cococodji, not far from Cotonou, with her children and husband. Together, the couple supports the family. Aïchatou Elise dropped out of high school and learned to do hair. For 8 years, she has worked as a hairdresser. She also sells cosmetic products and locks of hair in her hairdresser's shop in Cococodji. She buys her supplies In Dantokpa, the international market of Bénin, and in Lomé, Togo, a country bordering Bénin. She previously received one loan from ALIDé which she repaid in full. Wanting to expand her business and meet more customers' needs, Aïchatou Elise is asking for another loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of 4 Cartons of Cosmetics and 5 Dozen Locks of Hair

loans.name: Elizabeth Bih

texts.en:
Elizabeth Bih is a married mother of nine currently living in Ntualan in the Mankon district of Cameroon.  

Elizabeth has faced significant challenges throughout life.  The most difficult was the death of her child.  Through her period of mourning her community came together and were a great support for her.  She hopes to give back by providing a means to purchase many items that are not easily found in her area.  Items such as white meat, as well as manure for farming, will help her community and shorten the distance people will need to travel for basic necessities.  

Specifically, Elizabeth is hoping to secure a loan from GHAPE in order to purchase feed for her livestock, pay the rent for her store’s location and buy various items for resale including beans, rice, salt and groundnuts.  Elizabeth considers that her endeavors will continue to thrive because of her expertise.  Her store is one of the few in her area so she has several loyal customers that buy in bulk.  Similarly, her understanding of the composition of chicken feed and the large space on her compound where they can roam should lead to continued gains in the raising and sale of livestock.    

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Feed for livestock, rent for store location, retail items including rice, salt, beans, maggi among other items.

loans.name: Modinat

texts.en:
Modinat is 40 years old and married with four children. She is a member of Kiva partner, LAPO.
For the past five years Modinat has run a business selling body cream. One of her greatest joys is the one-on-one interaction she has with her customers. She is requesting a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more body cream to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more body cream to sell

loans.name: Gulab-E- Asel Group

texts.en:
This group, Gulab-e- Asel, has seven female members. Fazella is the group leader, and she is a good tailor. She needs money to buy a new machine with the other materials. 

Maleha wants to take a loan for her brother’s metal shop, who would like to complete his requirements. Jamila wants to take a loan for her husband’s retail shop. Shahesta would like to take a loan for her tailoring business and she would like to buy a new tailoring machine to sew more good design clothes for her clients to receive their satisfaction.Bashira’s brother has got shoe sewing shop. He needs money to purchase more materials for his shop. Hasiba wants to take a loan for her husband’s taxi, which needs a new machine. And the last member, Hamida, would like to receive the loan for her husband’s retail shop; mostly she helps him in cleaning and organizing the shop as well as house chores. 

They have all requested a group loan of 70000 Afghani and finally would like to thank the Kiva lenders.

loans.use: expanding their businesses and completing their requirements

loans.name: Yinka

texts.en:
Yinka is 34 years old and is married with three children. Her husband is a carpenter. She lives in Ibadan, Oyo State, Nigeria.

Yinka sells colorful sarongs at retail prices to her customers. She is a friendly woman and she uses her friendliness skills to attract more customers to her stall.

This is the high season for her business and Yinka hopes to meet the demands of her customers. She is requesting a loan of 100,000 NGN to purchase more sarongs to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Joienel

texts.en:
Joienel Y. is a 29-year-old male entrepreneur. He is married to Jovelyn, also 29, a housewife. Their eldest child is now in grade school while the other two are at home as they are not yet of school age. They all live together in a village called Balubad (cashew) in Silang, Cavite. Joienel’s general store is now three years old and has been growing successfully over the years. He registers more than 10,000 PHP in net income monthly.
Joienel enjoys the many benefits provided by Kiva partner, the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative, to its members. He not only enjoys the loans provided by the cooperative to support his business, but also the company of other entrepreneurs in the community. Now on his sixth loan cycle, Joienel is hoping that he will be granted a new loan of 10,000 PHP to purchase more merchandise, such as rice and soft drinks. He looks forward to converting his small store into a large grocery store some day.

About CCT
The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase more merchandise, such as rice and soft drinks

loans.name: Adjeley Adam

texts.fr: Mme W. Adam est couturière de profession 38 d'age elle a optenu son diplôme de couture à L'ICCP du TOGO. Trés top elle a abondoné ces etudes en classe de CE2 pour apprendre la couture.Une expérience dans la confection des chemises pour hommes. Elle sollicite une premier crédit de 300 000 F CFA sur une durée de 10 mois pour acheter des tissus et autres produits entrant dans la fabrication des chemises.
texts.en:
Mrs. Adam W. is a seamstress by profession. She is 38-years-old. She received her seamstress diploma at L'ICCP in Togo. At the top of her class, she left school in 2nd grade to learn to sew. She is experienced in making men's dress shirts. She is asking for her first loan of 300,000 FCFA over a period of 10 months to buy fabric and other products which go into the making of dress shirts.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of Fabric and Other Materials for Men's Dress Shirts

loans.name: Julienne

texts.fr: A. Julienne est née en 1960 à Sèmè au Bénin, et vit depuis près de 19 ans à Cocotomey non loin de Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Julienne est mariée à AGNILE Aristide, un revendeur. Le couple a cinq enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Julienne vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Grâce aux revenus issus de son activité, Julienne assure ensemble avec son mari les charges de la famille. Julienne n'a pas été à l'école. il y a trois ans déjà que Julienne vend des tubercules d'igname à Cocotomey, non loin de son domicile. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Julienne s'approvisionne. Julienne a obtenu une fois de crédit auprès de ALIDé, crédit qu'elle a bien remboursé. Dans l'optique d'augmenter son fonds de roulement pour vendre ses produits au marché de Cocotomey, afin d'accroître son chiffre d'affaire, Julienne sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Julienne A. was born in 1960 in Sèmè au Bénin. For 19 years, she has lived in Cocotomey, not far from Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. Julienne is married to Aristide Agnile, a salesman. The couple has five children who are all in school. Julienne lives together with her children and her husband. Thanks to the income from her job, Julienne and her husband care for the financial needs of their family together. Julienne did not go to school. It has been three years since Julienne started selling yam tubers in Cocotomey, not far from her home. She buys her stock In Dantokpa, the international market of Bénin. Julienne received one loan from ALIDé which she repaid in full. Intending to increase her stock to sell at the Cocotomey market and increase her sales, Julienne is asking for a second loan from ALIDé

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of 2 bags of Yam Tubers

loans.name: Sunday

texts.en:
Sunday is 48 years old and is married with five children. His wife is a teacher and she owns her own school.

Sunday sells textbooks to make a living. He sells for long hours to enable him put food on his table to feed his family members. He hopes to own a big bookshop in future.

Sunday is requesting a loan of 100,000 NGN to purchase more textbooks to sell. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more textbooks to sell

loans.name: Erlindi

texts.en:
Mrs. Erlindi S. is from the village of Calaran, Calamba, Misamis Occidental. She is 47 years old, a widow, and is blessed with three adult children. Her income comes primarily from her pension of 15,000 monthly.

In 2005, Erlindi joined PMPC to gain access to its financial services and programs. She is requesting a new loan of 35,000 PHP which will be used to repaint her house. This loan will be her 6th from PMPC.


About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To use for repainting her house

loans.name: Omolade

texts.en: Omolade is excited to take a Kiva loan with LAPO. She will use this loan to invest in a business selling natural honey which she will buy in bulk to get a better price. She is 35 years old, married, and has 2 children. She helps her husband to support the family. She is requesting for a loan amount of NGN150,000 to purchase more natural honey to sell. She says thank you to all kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more honey to sell.

loans.name: Funke's Group

texts.en: Funke loves Ibadan because it is a commercial city and she makes a lot of profit in this city. She sells sarongs, clothes and bags, at retail prices, to her customers. She hopes to own a boutique in the future. This is the high season for sales and she hopes to meet the demands of her customers. She is 42 years old, married, and has 4 children. Her husband is a mechanic and he also supports the family. She is requesting for a loan in the amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more sarongs, clothes and bags to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs, clothes and bags to sell.

loans.name: Ayaba

texts.fr: T. Ayaba est née le 04 Juillet 1963 à Ouidah, ville historique du Bénin. Ayaba vit depuis environs 11 ans à Cococodji, non loin de Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à KONATE Raïmi, un chauffeur, Ayaba est mère de deux enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. En plus de ses enfants, Ayaba a un autre enfant à charge. Ayaba vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Ayaba a arrêté l'école au cours secondaire. Depuis environs 5 ans, Ayaba vend des friperies à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C'est à Dantokpa et à Missèbo, un marché de friperies au Bénin, que Ayaba fait ses achats. Ayaba a obtenu une fois déjà de crédit à Alidé, crédit qu'elle a bien remboursé. C'est pour augmenter son stock de produits et mieux satisfaire ses clients, que Ayaba sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Ayaba T. was born July 4th, 1963 in Ouidah, a historic town in Bénin. For about 11 years, Ayaba has lived in Cococodji, not far from Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. Married to Raïmi Konate, a driver, Ayaba is the mother of two children who are both in school. In addition to her own children, Ayaba takes care of another child. She lives together with her husband and children. Together the couple financially supports the family. Ayaba dropped out of school in high school. For about 5 years, Ayaba has sold second-hand clothes in Bénin, where she also makes her purchases. Ayaba already received one loan from Alidé which she repaid in full. In order to increase her stock of products and better meet her clients' demands, she is asking for a second loan from Alidé.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of 4 Bales of Second-Hand Clothing

loans.name: Sona

texts.fr: Madame TITUS T. 39 ans est marié mère de deux enfants et un autre à sa charge elle est membre à la caisse de liberté 6 et habite à dieupeul non loin de la caisse. Son activité principale est l'aviculture elle achete des poussins qu'elle éleve  pour les revendre  sur le marché. Son expérience dans ce domaine lui vaut un deuxième crédit de 500 000 F CFA sur une durée de 12 mois elle compte sur ce crédit pour accroitre ses activités et aider son mari sur les depenses familialles.
texts.en:
Mrs. Titus T. is a 39-year-old, married woman. She has two children of her own and takes care of a third child. She is a member of the Liberté 6 bank branch and lives in Dieupeul, not far from the bank. She is primarily a poultry farmer. She buys chicks, raises them, and resells them at the market. With her experience, she is asking for a second loan of 500,000 FCFA over a period of 12 months. She is counting on this loan to increase her business and help her husband with the family's expenses.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Investment in a New Hen House

loans.name: Joyce Wanjiru

texts.en:
Joyce Wanjiru is a 57 year old married lady. She is a farmer and sells food items (vegetables, potatoes) and plastic items (bowls, cups, plates) in her retail shop, which is her primary business. She has been running the shop for about ten years and she earns a profit of about 20,000 Kenya shillings per month. Her customers are average income earners. In the picture we can see her with the secondary income base, which is her dairy cow whereby she also sells milk to her neighbours.

She is among the founding members of her borrowing group and this will be Joyce's fourth loan with KADET. She wants to use the loan to buy additional food items and plastic containers to sell to customers in her retail shop. 

She hopes to expand to a general shop that includes selling hardware and to manage a bigger farm with about eight cows to maximize her income opportunities.

loans.use: To purchase food items (vegetables, potatoes) and plastic containers to sell to customers.

loans.name: Njeri

texts.en:
Njeri is 35 years old, married, and has three children. She has a shop where she offers printing services and also sells stationery. She has been in the business for a period of about five years with a profit of about 80000 KES a month. 

She has not borrowed from another MFI and was introduced to KADET by a friend. With his loan, she plans to buy a fax machine, add stock of printing papers and stationery and to buy other accessories to sell to customers. This is her first loan with KADET and with the profits from this loan, she hopes to expand her areas of business and to start importing cars from abroad to sell to locals.

loans.use: To buy a fax machine and to add stock of printing papers and stationery and accessories.

loans.name: Musibau

texts.en: Musibau is 25 years old, married, and has a child. His wife sells ice cream to support the home. He is a friendly man and he uses his friendly skills to attract more customers to his stall. He sells engine oil at retail prices to his customers. He hopes to sell engine oil at wholesale prices in the future. He is requesting for a loan in the amount of NGN 50,000 to purchase more engine oil to sell. He says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more engine oil to sell.

loans.name: Abiola

texts.en: Abiola is 40 years old and married with two children. Her husband is a civil servant and together they support the home. To earn a living, Abiola sells bottles of wine and groceries at retail prices in Ibadan, Oyo State, Nigeria. In the future, she hopes to own a supermarket. She is requesting a loan of 80,000 NGN to purchase more wine and groceries to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more wine and groceries to sell

loans.name: Mouna

texts.en: Mouna is a 44-year-old married woman with 4 children, of whom 2 are still going to school. She has owned a shoe and bag shop since 2007 to earn income to raise  her family well. Today, Mouna is asking to borrow US$ 1,000 to purchase additional merchandise to satisfy the needs of the market.

loans.use: to purchase additional merchandise

loans.name: Sadia

texts.en: Sadia is 42 years old and married to a pastor. They are blessed with 2 lovely children. She is a hard-working woman and she is determined to lift her business and family above poverty. She sells groceries at retail prices to her customers to earn a living. She hopes to purchase groceries at wholesale prices in the future to enable her to give a discount to her customers. She is requesting the loan amount of 50,000 NGN to purchase more groceries to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en: Mohamad has owned a car painting shop since 2000. He’s 24 years old, single and living with his parents. He has great demand for his shop thus he wants to  take out  a  loan of US$ 1000 to buy more tools and enlarge his shop to meet the requirements of his clients and make a good income for his family.

loans.use: buy more tools

loans.name: Josephine

texts.fr: A. Josephine est née en 1954 à Agbangnizoun au Bénin. Josephine vit depuis 10 ans à Cocotomey, non loin de Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. C'est une veuve et mère de 5 enfants, tous scolarisés. Josephine vit seule avec ses enfants, et supporte seule les charges de la famille. Josephine n'a pas été à l'école. Il y a 5 ans environs que Josephine vend des condiments de sauce (piment, moutarde locale, tomate fraîche, oignons, gingembre, etc.) et également de l'huile de palme et des poissons frits à son domicile et au marché Pahou, dans la commune de Ouidah, ville historique du Bénin. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Josephine s'approvisionne. Josephine a obtenu une fois de crédit à ALIDé, crédit qui a été bien remboursé. En vue d'augmenter son fonds de roulement et d'agrandir son activité, Josephine sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Josephine A. was born in 1954 in Agbangnizoun, Bénin. For 10 years she has lived in Cocotomey, not far from Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. She is a widowed mother of 5 children, all of whom are in school. Josephine lives alone with her children and is the sole family breadwinner. She did not go to school. About 5 years ago, Josephine began selling sauce condiments (chili pepper, local mustard, fresh tomato, onion, ginger, etc.), palm oil, and fried fish from her home and at the Pahou market in the Ouidah community, a historic village in Bénin. Josephine buys her supplies in Dantokpa, the international market of Bénin. She received a first loan from ALIDé which she repaid in full. Wanting to increase her income and grow her business, Josephine is asking for a second loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of 1 Basket of Peppers, 2 Baskets of Fresh Tomatoes and one Sack of Onions

loans.name: Nawale

texts.en: Nawale is a 43-year-old married woman with 3 children. In 1997, after having her 3 children, she decided to help her husband by working as a home-based tailor to earn additionA. income for the family. Today, NawA. is asking to borrow US$ 1,000 to buy a new sewing machine in place of the used one to continue her work properly and present more products to her clients.

loans.use: buy a new sewing machine

loans.name: Night

texts.en:
C. Night is currently in the business of selling medicinal drugs in a shop and is requesting a loan to purchase more drugs to sell. Night is 34 years old and is divorced. She has 5 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a retail shop. BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase more drugs to sell

loans.name: Walaa

texts.en:
Walaa is an 18-year-old single woman. Four years ago she learned hairstyling and, in 2007, she decided to open her own beauty salon and began a new career.

Today, Walaa is requesting $1,200 to buy products needed for her salon.

loans.use: To buy products needed for her salon

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase an additional stock of ingredients in bulk

loans.name: Rana

texts.en:
Rana has owned a beauty salon in her town since 2004 with eight years of previous experience. She is 31 years old and the mother of two young children. She helps her husband to provide a better life for the family.

Today, Rana is asking to borrow $1,200 to purchase items such as a laser machine and a wax machine to satisfy the demands of her clients and to enlarge her business.

loans.use: To purchase items for her salon

loans.name: Kibanebane Group

texts.en:
Haidari D., age 46, is a married man with three children aged 21, 19, and 9 years. He has owned a traditional medicine business for 4 years now. He works daily from 7:30 am until 8 pm and from the business is able to make a monthly profit of around $264.

This will be Haidari’s 2nd loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He used the previous loan to expand his business stock and paid back his loan successfully. He hopes to get a loan from Tujijenge Tanzania to further increase his stock of traditional medicines.

Haidari will share this loan with his loan group, Kibanene, which totals 20 members. The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Haidari is in front in a blue shirt.

loans.use: stock for his traditional medicine business

loans.name: Singida Group

texts.en:
Mariam Omary, age 32, is single.  She has had a clothes, bag, and sarong and fabrics business for one year now.  She works daily from 10 am until 12 pm. She is able to make a monthly profit of around $483.

This will be Mariam’s 1st loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She hopes for a loan from Tujijenge to increase her capital.
	
Mariam will share this loan with her loan group,  Singida, which totals 16 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Mariam is 2nd from the left, front row.

loans.use: To increase the capital for her fabrics business

loans.name: Ama

texts.fr: Cette femme habite dans le quartier d’apédokoè qui est un quartier périphérique de la ville de Lomé, elle exerce comme  activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de charbons de bois. Elle s’approvisionne au marché local d’assiyéyé. Son stock de charbons de bois a connu une baisse, elle voudrait se réapprovisionner raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat de 30 sacs de charbons de bois, elle s’approvisionne à l’intérieur du pays dans la ville de Sokodé, ainsi elle arrive à réaliser un grosse marge bénéficiaire sur ses ventes.
texts.en:
This woman lives in Apédokoè, which is an outlying district of the city of Lomé. Her revenue-generating business involves commerce in charcoal. She stocks up at the local marketplace in Assiyéyé. Her stock of charcoal experience a drop. She would like to stock up again. This is why she's requesting a loan from WAGES to buy 30 sacks of charcoal. She stocks up from the country's interior in the city of Sokodé, and so she manages to realize a large profit margin on her sales.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying charcoal

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional stock of salt in bulk

loans.name: Aisosa

texts.en: Aisosa sells dried fish at retail prices to her customers. The demand for her dried fish is high. Dried fish is used in the preparation of local soups like 'banga', 'egusi' and okra in Nigeria. This is the high season for her business and she hopes to meet the demand of her customers. She is 43 years old, married with 3 children. Her husband sells building materials to also support the household. She hopes for a loan amount of 120,000 NGN to purchase more dried fish to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more dried fish to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of maize flour in bulk

loans.name: Houmassi

texts.fr: Cette dame est mariée et mère de 03 enfants, elle a ouvert sa propre boutique dans laquelle elle fait des services de secrétariat. Elle a associé à cette activité le commerce des articles scolaires. Elle a déjà obtenu 2 fois du crédit qu’elle a bien remboursé, elle souhaiterait redynamiser son commerce, elle sollicite alors de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat de 2 cartons de papiers A4, 10 boîtes de trombones, 3 boîtes de stylos et divers articles scolaires.
texts.en:
This is a lady who is married and the mother of three. She opened her own shop in which she provides secretarial services. She has included with this business the sale of school supplies. She has twice had a loan already that she has repaid. She would like to re-energize her business. She's therefore requesting a loan from WAGES to buy two boxes of A4 paper, ten boxes of paper clips, three boxes of ink pens, and a variety of school items.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: A4 paper, boxes of paper clips, boxes of pens, etc.

loans.name: Tchamélé

texts.fr: Cette dame est mariée et mère de 05 enfants, elle vit avec sa famille dans le quartier d’adidogomé. Elle a ouvert un débit de boissons qu’elle a appelé « Ets ADAKA », elle a ouvert cet atelier depuis 2002. Son stock de boisson a connu une baisse, elle souhaiterai se réapprovisionner et demande à WAGES un crédit pour l’achat de 30 casiers de bière et 20 casiers de sucrerie. Avec ce stock, elle compte réaliser un excellent chiffre d’affaire.
texts.en:
This is a lady who is married and the mother of five children. She lives with her family in the Adidogomé district. She opened a beverages outlet that she called "Ets ADAKA". She opened this shop in 2002. Her stock of drinks has experience a drop. She would like to stock up again and is asking WAGES for a loan to buy 30 cases of beer and 20 cases of soft drinks. With this loan, she expects to have excellent sales figures.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying beverages

loans.name: Lsaac

texts.en:
Isaac has a grinding machine that he uses to grind foodstuffs for his customers. The demands for his services are high in his community in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. He works for long hours to enable him meet the basic needs and necessities of his family.

Isaac is 45 years old and is married with three children. His wife sells foodstuffs to support the home.

Isaac hopes for a loan of 60,000 NGN to purchase a grinding machine. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase a grinding machine

loans.name: Sunday

texts.en: Sunday E. is 50 years old and is married to a doctor. She has one child who does not go to school. Sunday is currently in the business of selling food in a restaurant and is requesting a loan to purchase crates of beer and sodas to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, Sunday hopes to be able to open up a retail shop. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase crates of beer and sodas to sell

loans.name: Rose Aoko

texts.en: Rose O., 34, sells clothes in Rangala/Ungunja.  She has been in this business for 7 years and her primary customers are parents who need school uniform for their children, and locals with basic clothes needs.
