Es bien trabajadora; en las mañanas se dedica a cuidar 3 niños y realiza trabajo de limpieza por las tardes y en la noche sale a vender sus hamburguesas.
Gracias a su trabajo y dedicación a logrado sacar adelante a sus hijos quienes van a postular a la universidad y por ello solicita el financiamiento para llevar acabo el sueño de poder brindarles una educación superior a ellos.  
La Sra. goza de buenas referencias de parte de los vecinos y de sus comensales quienes manifiestan que es bien tratable y amable.
texts.en:
Ms. Ivette G. L. is 37 years old and lives in Botijeria Angulo Norte-near Ica. She lives in the home of a relative with her 2 children; one is 18 years old and the other is a young woman, 16 years old. She sells hamburgers, chicken, soft drinks and other things. Her business is located outside of her home and she has been involved in this activity for 5 years. She is very hard-working; in the morning, she takes care of 3 children and in the afternoon, she cleans and then in the evening, she goes to sell her hamburgers. Thanks to her work and dedication, she has been able to make progress and her children are going to apply to university. For this reason, she is requesting this loan in order to achieve the dream of giving her children a post-secondary education. Ms. G. L. has good references from her neighbors and her customers who say she is congenial and friendly.

Translated from Spanish by Lauren Jackson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to cover personal expenses

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina B. is from the city of Migcanaway, Tangub City. She is 32 years old and married with four school-aged children. To make a living, Gina owns and operates a business harvesting and selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Gina has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately $75 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Gina joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation by engaging in business activities. Gina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from GDMPC. She is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to repair  equipment used in the business. This will be her 2nd loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair equipment used in the business

loans.name: Chhay

texts.en:
Chhay P., age 24, is a young, good mother, caring for her two kids. Neither of them is enrolled in school yet and are dependent on her. To earn a living, Chhay P. has a rental kiosk inside the local market where she sells fresh fish that she buys in bulk from her wholesale supplier.

She is married to Lean Seng, 22, who is a construction foreman. Chhay P.’s husband has been very busy at his construction business due to there being many customers who need him to build their house, but he is lacking materials to perform his service. That is why Chhay P. is applying for a loan of $900 to purchase more building materials. She will use some of the proceeds of the loan to improve her fish-selling business.

loans.use: To purchase more building material

loans.name: Chhay

texts.en: Mr. Chhay T. is a single 24-year-old man, currently living with his mother, who is pictured above.  Chhay is an internal staff member for a Hotel in Siem Reap province, earning a salary of $120 each month. Another source of family income is his mother’s business. She cultivates a rice crop in the village. Chhay has faced difficulties traveling to his work place, and he pays a lot of money for a taxi to go there. Because of that, he is applying for a loan to purchase an old motorbike which he will use for riding to work.

loans.use: To purchase an old motorbike which he will use for riding to work

loans.name: Reynaldo

texts.en:
This is Reynaldo B., 60, a store owner and transport operator from Lumil, Silang, Cavite.  He is married to Liberty, 45, a housewife.  

Reynaldo has been in business for twenty years.  He manages his own general store which has grown through the years.  He also manages the operation of their passenger jeepney (minibus), plying varied routes around town.  Combined, he earns more than $875 a month in net profits.

Reynaldo was a bit hesitant when he joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2007.  He thought this was just for women entrepreneurs, but he found that to be incorrect, and now he loves to invite other entrepreneurs to join the cooperative.  Reynaldo wants to share with his friends the many blessings he has received since joining the CCT.  He currently needs a loan of 40,000 PHP to improve his general store.  He will use it to stock up on more merchandise for his store.  



About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: to purchase more merchandise to sell

loans.name: Jovita

texts.en:
Jovita C. is 55 years old and married to her caring and loving husband Partricio C., a 59-year-old driver. They live in the village of Sitio Tubigan, Antipolo Rizal. She has been engaged in a hog-fattening business (raising pigs) for almost 10 years with the support of her loving husband and her respectful children. Her two children graduated as degree holders through loans from the Kiva field partner Ahon SA Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), and Mary Jane, the youngest one, is a graduating college student.

Jovita C. will use the loan to raise more pigs and for the expansion of her future hog-farming business. She also plans to buy a motorcycle with a sidecar in order to support her family in a stable life. She hopes she will enjoy the proceeds of her business and make a good living. 

She also enjoys the advantage of having loans from ASHI because she can progressively achieve her goals in life. During almost 10 years with ASHI, Jovita has made herself known as an industrious woman who has determination and discipline, and she believes that having this attitude will lead to her family dream. Because of her urgency and because she is a good-quality mother, she gives her children the best education. She is determined to do her business because of her knowledge and because she wants to improve her financial situation. In the future, she plans to expand the business for long-term use.

loans.use: raise more pigs, expand her business, and purchase a motorcycle with sidecar for the business.

loans.name: 02.03.1.8 Nam Ngạn Group

texts.en:
"Huệ Ngô Thị (39) is a 43-year-old female living in the town of Thanh Hoá.  Huệ is the group leader of a four-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 02.03.1.8 Nam Ngạn (02.03.1.8 Nam Ngạn).


Huệ is married and has two adult children.  To make a living, Huệ owns and operates a business selling rice products in the local community.  Huệ has been engaged in this business for over fifteen years and earns approximately $165 a month from these activities.


In 2009, Huệ joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation by engaging in business activities.  Huệ has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1,626,900 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale.  She is now requesting a new loan of 6,000,000 VND which again will be used to purchase morer raw ingredients needed to make products for sale.  This will be her 2nd loan from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Huệ plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  N. Thị Chinh (40) is a 44-year-old female who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector running a bakery.


2.  Ngô Thị T. Hằng (41) is a 27-year-old female who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her business in the service sector operating a service-based business.


3.  P. Thị Hà (42) is a 43-year-old female who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her business in the retail sector running a general store.


About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Huệ Ngô Thị (39) là 43 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hoá.  Huệ là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 4 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 02.03.1.8 Nam Ngạn (02.03.1.8 Nam Ngạn).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên T. nhập, mà nguồn T. nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ buôn bán các sản phẩm từ gạo trong cộng đồng địa phương.  Huệ thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 15 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Huệ kiếm được khoảng 3.000.000 VND.  Vào 2009, Huệ đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Huệ đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 1.626.900 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua các thành phần thô cần thiết để chế tạo sản phẩm để bán.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6.000.000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 2nd khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  N. Thị Chinh (40) là 44 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh lò bánh mì.


2.  Ngô Thị T. Hằng (41) là 27 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh trên cơ sở dịch vụ.


3.  P. Thị Hà (42) là 43 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hàng bách hóa.


Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Linda

texts.en:
Linda A. is a 56-year-old general store owner from Iba, Silang, Cavite.  Her husband Merlito, 52, is a fisherman.  They have four children; one is in high school and three are in grade school.
 
Linda owns a general store which has been around for five years.  Through the years, her general store has grown steadily.  She now earns a net income of close to $110 a month.   She uses her profits to support her children’s education and to pay for their daily needs.   

She is now on her third loan cycle with the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative.  She has recently applied for a new loan amounting to 9,000 PHP.  She will use the fund to purchase more items to sell at her general store.  Linda dreams of enlarging her general store into a big grocery store someday.  



About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: to purchase more items to sell

loans.name: Phat

texts.en: Phat M., age 27, is the young father of a child who is not yet enrolled in school. Phat owns a piece of farmland that he inherited from his grandparents. On his land, he grows different kinds of crops, such as rice and some vegetables. His wife stays at home to care for their child and sometimes sells a few groceries to her neighbors for a profit. Phat M.’s wife has been very busy at her business due to there being many clients who need to buy her items, but she does not have enough inventory to meet her customers' needs. That is why Phat M. needs a loan to buy more groceries to sell.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to sell

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
At her young age, she is blissfully married to Leo M., 26 years old, and makes sets of furniture from bamboo. They are happily living on the Island of Talim, Binangonan Rizal. She is blessed with her two children, Adrian and Francis May.

She is a poor woman, and because she wanted to rise from poverty, she encouraged herself to join ASHI, an MFI and Kiva field partner, to access capital to start up a business. She received the amount of 5,000 PHP for her first loan, and she was able to utilize it in her business, the making of bamboo sets (furniture). The business still exists. On her fourth loan she is asking for 17,000 PHP for the same business. She will purchase bamboo, rolls of bamboo strips, nails and other equipment for making furniture. She also plans to expand her business to get involved in double-deck making (bunk beds) for more income.

She wants to have savings for their future needs, especially because she hopes to send her children to school until they finish college. She dreams that her children will be professionals in order for them to live a happy and contented life.

That is the story of a simple, baby-faced and courageous mother, only 23 years old, Jocelyn M..

loans.use: to buy bamboo, bamboo strips, nails, etc. for the growth of her business

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia D. L., 60, is an entrepreneur who lives in Lumil, Silang, Cavite with her only child, who is in college, and her husband Guillermo, 54.
 
Virginia manages her own food canteen located at the heart of the village.  It has been around for four years now.   She also runs a general store along with the canteen. She earns a net income of more than $560 a month.  She uses her profits for the continuous operation of her canteen.  Most of her family’s basic daily needs are from the proceeds of her business, including the college expenses of her child.  

Virginia currently needs a loan of 20,000 PHP for the continuous operation of her business.  She has been dreaming of establishing a branch in another part of the province.



About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: to purchase more items to sell

loans.name: Mot

texts.en: Mr. Mot K. is a 28 years old and a resident of Siem Reap province. He is a single man and currently lives with his supportive mother, who appears in the picture above. To make a living, Mot K. works in construction, earning approximately $4 per day. He also helps his mother in doing farm work when he is free from his job. In the past, Mot K. has paid a lot of money for a taxi to go to work because he does not own a vehicle. To cut this cost, Mot K. has requested a loan to buy a used motorcycle which will allow him to drive to his work location.

loans.use: To buy a used motorcycle which will allow him to drive to his work location

loans.name: Lount

texts.en: Mrs. Lount K., 23, is married to Choun Cheda, 28, and they earn their living from fishing. Lount K. and her husband always rise early to prepare their tools and go to the middle of river by boat to fish. After they finish fishing, they hurry to bring their fresh catch to the market to sell retail. They can make an income of about $5 per day. This couple has two school-aged children at home in their small house located along the river. Lount K. will be use her loan to buy extra tools and to repair their old ones.

loans.use: To buy extra tools and to repair their old ones

loans.name: Annabelle

texts.en:
Annabelle D. is from the village of Brgy. Quirino, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 36 years old, married, and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Annabelle owns & operates a business in the retail sector, running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of  products in the local community. Annabelle has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month.

In 2009, Annabelle joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Annabelle is requesting her first loan, in the amount of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
This is Margaret M., 33 years old.  She lives with her siblings in Magtibay St., Pasay City.  She owns a general store which she opened five years ago, and business has steadily grown over the years.  Because of consumer demand, she also added selling pre-paid electronic load credits for mobile phones.  Business is brisk and she constantly makes close to P9, 000.00 a month in net income.  
Margaret found time to attend a gathering organized for women entrepreneurs by the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2008 and eventually became a member after a series of orientation sessions.  She is now applying for a loan in the amount of P15, 000.00 for the continuous operation of her business.  She will buy more grocery items to sell at her store.  Margaret looks forward to pursuing her dream of working overseas. 



About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: purchase of more grocery items to sell at her store

loans.name: Jeramie

texts.en:
At 27 years old, Jeramie is blissfully married to Jay-ar, 29 years old, taho vendor, and they live happily with her two children, Justine and Jaymie, elementary grade school students. Jeramie lives in the mountainous province of Antipolo, Rizal, Philippines, where there is a lot of opportunity to start up a business and to look forward to making a living. 

Jeramie is an underprivileged woman who aspires to rise out of poverty. She totally decided to join ASHI, an MFI and KIVA field partner, to access more capital for the growth of her business. She has been engaged in TAHO vending (“taho” means a kind of food made of soya, ready to eat) for almost two years. She plans to use her proposed loan of 20,000.00 pesos to expand her business and to get involved in selling frozen foods and beauty products at the market in order to earn a good income.

Jeramie desires a joyful life and a good income so her children can finish their studies until college. To realize all of these aspirations and hopes, she is "knocking your good heart" to support her simple dreams by means of supporting her loans.

loans.use: to purchase taho ingredients, frozen foods and beauty products

loans.name: Penh

texts.en: Penh S., 46, is married and the good mother of four children - one married and three single. Penh S. owns various fishing materials which she and her husband use to fish in and around Tunle Sap River, where they can generate $6 of income each day. Penh S. has been depending on this activity for more than nine years. She hopes to accumulate more fishing tools and is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase them. With the remainder of the loan, she will update the size of the kitchen of her existing house.

loans.use: To purchase more tools to fish

loans.name: Rosaline

texts.en: This is Rosaline C., a young entrepreneur who lives in Pasay City, a bustling community in the middle of the metropolis. She is 34 years old and her husband, Arnel, 38, is a driver. One of their four children is in high school and two are in grade school. Rosaline has a stall near the Libertad Public Market selling mobile phones and other phone accessories. She also manages the operation of their fleet of three motorized tricycles. She earns more than P33,000 a month. Her profits answer for her family’s basic daily needs, especially her children’s education. Rosaline became a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2002. She has applied for a new loan of P17,000 with the cooperative as additional capital for her business. She dreams of seeing all her children remain in school until they finish their studies. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business

loans.name: Keao

texts.en: Keao M., 47, is married with two teenage children,  who attend school. He has a job as a local barber and rents a small workshop, located along the road, to provide this service. Most of his clients are men who live in the commune. He normally generates an average of $4 profit a day and uses his income to meet all his family’s needs. Keao M. is applying for a loan from Kiva’s partner HKL which he will use to buy different kinds of cooking ingredients for his wife to sell. This will allow him to accumulate more income to ensure that his family attains a better standard of living.

loans.use: To buy different kinds of cooking ingredients for his wife to sell

loans.name: Brenda Lee

texts.en: This is Brenda Lee B., a 34-year-old entrepreneur from Cabrera, Pasay City. One of her three children is in high school and the other two are in grade school. Her husband, Victor, is a cook. Brenda has been buying and selling processed meats like longanisa (local sausage) and embutido (meat loaf) and hotdogs for five years now. In addition, she also sells soft drinks and ready-to-wear (RTW) clothing. She now earns more than P8,000 a month in net income but her earnings sometimes vary depending on the supply and demand of frozen products. Brenda applied for a fresh loan of P24,000 from CCT so she can re-stock her frozen supplies. She wishes to see all her children finish their studies. She also dreams of having a stall in the market. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To re-stock her frozen goods

loans.name: Mercelita

texts.en:
Mercelita P., 43, hails from the province of Pangasinan but has migrated to Camarin, Caloocan City with her family.  She is married to Nathaniel, who is also 43, and a taxi driver.  The eldest of their two children is now in college and their other child is still in grade school.

Mercelita manages the operation of their taxi.  She also finds time making and selling home-made spring rolls and other preserved meat products.  She found it to be an interesting hobby and source of income as well.  Although she complains that subsequent oil price affects their taxi operation.  From her profits, she was able to purchase replacement tires for their taxi.

She joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative only this year.  She will use the funds for the preventive maintenance of the taxi.  She has been saving a lot so as to be able to buy more taxi units so she can help employ other people.




About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: preventive maintenance of the taxi

loans.name: Dourng

texts.en: Dourng E. was a 60 years old married mother. Her husband died of senility. She has six children, five of whom are married and live away from home and the other one is a daughter who is selling grocery items. Dourng E. currently teaches a class of secondary students and has been a local teacher since her children were very young. Recently, Dourng E.'s daughter has sold all her inventory and she hopes to resupply her stock but she doesn't have enough money yet. Dourng Emg wants to take out her first loan to help increase the inventory of her daughter’s selling grocery business.

loans.use: To help increase the inventory of her daughter’s selling grocery business

loans.name: Fermina

texts.en:
Fermina U. is from the village of Quirino Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 42 years old, married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Fermina owns & operates a beauty salon. Fermina has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Fermina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to grow her business. Fermina is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Fermina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: to purchase materials needed to provide service

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Seth

texts.en: Seth O., 51 years old, has built a shop in front of her home where she operates and sells various cooking ingredients. She sells her items to people who live near her house and typically makes around $4 of profit each day to meet what her family needs. Beside her grocery business, she owns a few rooms that she uses for a karaoke service. She is married to Doul Seng, 61, who assists with her in selling inventory. Seth O. has five kids, two of whom are working as cleaners for a small firm and the rest of them are students in the local school. In the past, Seth O. hired a taxi at high cost to deliver her merchandise and right now she hopes to reduce the fee by using a loan to purchase a new motorcycle, which she will use to supply her business.

loans.use: To purchase a new motorcycle, which she will use to supply her business

loans.name: Maria Rosanna

texts.en: This is Maria Rosanna M., who is 45 years old. She is married to Edgar, 53, a company driver. Two of their children are now working. They live in Good Harvest Subdivision, Caloocan City. Maria Rosanna has been selling vegetables and other cooked food items for two years in her family's village. She enjoys her work because she gets to meet all sorts of people. She earns more than P 11,000.00 a month. When typhoons come, crops are damaged and so the price of vegetables go up, making it hard for Maria Rosanna to sell her items. She is now on her sixth loan with the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative. She joined the cooperative only last year. Maria Rosanna applied for a new loan in the amount of P 14,000.00 as additional capital for her food market business. Maria Rosanna desires to have her own bigger stall in the market. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines in pursuit of its desire to see lives changed, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase stocks of vegetables to sell and other cooked food items

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Koy

texts.en:
Koy S., 30, is a low-income person living in Siem Reap province. She raises many pigs in a stall next to her house, to earn her living. She learned the skill of raising pigs from her grandfather and has used her knowledge to earn money for years. Usually, she will sell all her pigs to a buyer four months after she begins raising them.

Koy S. is married with three young children, while her husband is a rice miller. To save money, Koy S. also collects the leftovers from rice milling to feed her pigs.

Because her pig business is very profitable, Koy S. is looking for capital to purchase many piglets to raise.

loans.use: To purchase many piglets to raise

loans.name: Maria Snooky

texts.en:
Maria Snooky S. believes that poverty is not the hindrance to fulfilling one’s dreams if you have the courage to pursue those hopes and dreams. Dreams in life give you the right direction to slowly changing your standard of living. Every step she made she planned with awareness, not blaming herself for the consequence of it. That’s what Maria Snooky S. values in life. 

Maria Snooky is married to Guillardo S., 35 years old and a fisherman. Five children are the fruits of their love. The eldest is 14 years old and the youngest is ten months old. Three of their children are in school.

In 2005, Maria Snooky motivated herself and her husband to join ASHI (Ahon sa Hirap, Inc.) a Kiva field partner. She carefully utilized her loans from ASHI for the growth of her business. Now, she is proposing Php 15,000 to pay for two sewing machines.

Maria Snooky is also engaged in a small business retailing different goods. She hopes to see her business in demand in their town. She dreams of having her own tailoring shop or being a sub-contractor with a lot of sewing machines someday and to extend to orders in bulk. She also has a desire to renovate their house and enable all her children to finish studies through college.

loans.use: To purchase two sewing machines

loans.name: Oeum

texts.en:
Oeum L., 46, has been married for some years; she and her husband have six children.  Two of their children are employed while the remaining four attend school. Oeum L. has been earning a living as a local grower since 2000. She grows vegetables on her own farmland, while her husband  decorates wood for buildings. 

Oeum L. wants to earn more income by raising ducks. Because Oeum L. doesn't have enough money, she would like to ask for a loan from Kiva through HKL to be used to buy ducks to breed for the purpose of producing eggs.

loans.use: To buy ducks to breed for producing eggs

loans.name: Penn

texts.en: Penn S. is 49 years old and married to Vin Sok, 45, a local fisherman. The couple has been married for many years and is blessed with five school-aged children, all dependent on their income. Penn S. owns a medium-size store next to her house where she sells Chinese noodles and soft drinks. She starts her business in the morning and sells to customers who are her nearby neighbors. To improve her business, Penn S. has decided to seek a Kiva loan to decorate her shop and to buy more essential materials for her enterprise.

loans.use: To decorate her shop and to buy more essential materials for her business

loans.name: Sea

texts.en:
Sea S. is a 47 year-old farmer living in the rural area of Siem Reap province, Cambodia (her husband is pictured above). Sea S. sells some vegetables that she grows on her own farmland. She plants her crops many times per year and earns $3 a day. Sea S. is a determined woman and the mother of two children, who are enrolled in school. 

Her husband assists her on the farm. Sea S. said that her current income is not adequate to support her family and she hopes to encourage her husband to attain another profitable job as a motorbike taxi driver, but she has no money to start it. Therefore, she decided to request a loan to purchase a used motorcycle which will allow her husband to provide a taxi service.

loans.use: To purchase a used motorcycle to start a taxi service

loans.name: Khoshi Mahbooba Group

texts.en:
This is the Khoshi Mahbooba group. It has four members. Zia Jan is the group leader. She lives in a family of seven. Her husband has a shop in which he sells dried fruit. She shares the work with him by cleaning fruits of their shells or rinds before they are sold. Hamida wants to take out a loan for her brother who sells clothes in his cart. Naz Parwar wants to take out a loan for her husband’s cosmetics shop so that he can buy more materials and make more profits, and the last member, Mahbooba, wants to get a loan for her husband who has a retail shop.

They have requested a group loan of 40,000 Afghani to progress in a better way.

loans.use: purchasing materials for their businesses

loans.name: Lily

texts.en:
Lily R., currently in the business of selling soft drinks in a restaurant, is requesting a loan to purchase beers, packaged juice, powdered milk, etc. to sell. Lily, 32 years old and married to a man who is currently a student, has one child who attends school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a plot of land and build a house to rent out.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase beer, juice, powdered milk, etc. to sell

loans.name: Dewa Group

texts.en:
This is Dewa group. This group is made up of three members. These three members have requested a group loan of 20000 Afghani.   

Meir Malang is the group leader. He is a man who is 38 years old. He is married, having 6 children, four sons and two daughters. He has a retail shop. And now his business income is low so he wants to expend his business and increase his business income. 

The second member is Gula, who is a tailor. Before emigrating she was sewing clothes. But now in Pakistan they have lots of economic problems so they left. Now by the Kiva loan she wants to buy a new sewing machine, clothes and wants to start her business in a new way to support her husband and children.

The last member is Dewa who has the business of beadworking. And through its income she supports her family members.

They would like to thank both AFS and Kiva lenders that support the people around the world through their effective process.

loans.use: They want to improve their businesses.

loans.name: Keji

texts.en: Keji L. is currently in the business of selling charcoal in the market and is requesting a loan to buy more bags of charcoal to sell. Keji is 29 years old and is married to a soldier. She has five children who all go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a shop. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en: Rehema is a 41 year married with seven children aged 15 and 19 years.  None of her children goes to school because she couldn’t raise school fees. She resides and owns a four roomed house where she is staying with six people. Rehema takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and no piped water and gets three meals a day.  She incurs transport costs to and from buying her fresh food staffs like sacks of bananas, sweet potatoes cassava, onions and tomatoes. Rehema has a stall selling fresh foods in Nakulabye. She works in a semi urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala  She works seven days a week .She receives an average of 20 customers a day and sells to all categories of people both on retail and wholesale  Her greatest monthly expenses include feeding the family, school fees for her children and monthly market dues. Her major business challenges are seasonality and rainy season which hinders her to reach her customers. She has been in this business for ten years and with MCDT for five years servicing her tenth loan, working with the same group mates. Dorothy joined MCDT because it was near her home and was working with poor women. She wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of banana sacks of cassava boxes of tomatoes ,onions . She wants to see her business   grower bigger and start selling on whole sale only.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of bananas,cassavaand toamatoes

loans.name: Dawa

texts.en:
Dawa P. is currently in the business of selling tea and bread in her restaurant and is requesting a loan to buy more bags of sugar, powdered milk etc to make more tea to sell.

Dawa is 37 years old and is married to a businessman. She has eight children who all go to school. With the extra profits from her loan she hopes to be able to open a retail shop.


About BRAC
BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more bags of sugar, powdered milk etc to make more tea to sell

loans.name: Adalet Basafa Group

texts.en:
This is Adalet Basafa group, which has four female members. Olya is the group leader. She is 48, married, and the mother of four children. She is a tailor and sews different kinds of clothes in her house. Olya wants to take out a loan to buy a new sewing machine, because she is having lots of problems with the old one.

The second member is Nazifa, who wants to take out a loan for her husband’s workshop. He repairs car parts in his workshop. With the Kiva loan, he wants to purchase required materials.

Bebe Gul, the third member, wants to buy necessary materials for her husband’s retail shop, which covers all of the family's household expenses. He would like to expand his business.

The last member, Saleha, has an embroidery business. With the loan, she would like to purchase necessary materials to support her progress.

They have requested a group loan of 56000 Afghani.

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine

loans.name: Lung

texts.en:
Mrs. Lung N. is a humble villager living in Siem Reap province. Lung N. was born in 1961 and has established her own small family with nine other members. 

To make a living, Lung N. and her husband always wake up when the sky is still dark to go to the middle of the river with their boat for fishing. 

After they finish fishing, they hurry to bring their fish to sell to the middlemen, who then take them to sell at retail in the market. Recently, Lung N. has  suspended her fishing business because her boat and some fishing equipment have broken, which affects her income. Thus, she has decided to request a loan for repairs.

loans.use: To repair boat and fishing equipment

loans.name: Bizard

texts.en:
Bizard E., 35, is married to Marlyn E. and together they are blessed with two children. The elder is studying in high school and the younger is in elementary school. The family lives in Dasmariñas, Cavite, a province just south of Manila.

Bizard E. is a sewer and does furniture upholstery. He has been a sewer for 17 years.

A member of Center for Community Transformation* for more than a year, he has already received six loans from CCT because of good attendance in their weekly fellowship meetings and his regular payment of dues. With the added capital that he received from CCT, his business grew and now he earns 12500 PHP net profit per month.

Because he sees that his business is flourishing, he now wants to further expand his business by applying for a 16000 PHP loan so that he can use it as added capital to buy more raw materials for making more furniture.

He prays that God will continually bless his business so that someday he can have his own upholstery shop full of clients and earn enough money for his kids to finish their studies until they graduate in college.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans

loans.use: To purchase leather and other material for making furniture.

loans.name: Lakulo

texts.en:
Lakulo L. is currently in the business of selling beans, groundnuts, and tomatoes in the market. She is requesting a loan to buy groundnuts that she can use to make paste to sell.

Lukulo is 32 years old and is married. Her husband is an engineer. She has two children and her children go to school.

With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a retail shop.

About BRAC

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members

loans.use: To buy groundnuts to use to make paste to sell.

loans.name: Sam

texts.en:
Mr. Sam V., 29, is a hard working man who resides in Siem Reap province.

(Sam was busy providing his services when the photo taken, so his wife is pictured instead.)

To pursue a daily income, Sam owns a trailer motorbike (Tuk Tuk) which he uses for a taxi service. Most of his clients are foreigners who need him to pick them up to visit Angkor Wat and other relaxable places.

He is able to earn around $8 each day to manage his family’s daily requirements.

His wife sells a little fish in the market and also takes time to either care for a lovely young child or do housework.

Sam will use his first loan to purchase a plot of farmland in the best location for farming, which he will rent to farmers for fees.

loans.use: To purchase a plot of farmland in the best location for farming, which he will rent to farmers for fees.

loans.name: Sokneang

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokneang K., 34, and her husband Mr. Theara Roeun, 35, live on an Island of the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

They have been married for 15 years and have three sons; two attend school and the youngest son stays at home.

Sokneang has been a silk weaver since she was 15 years old; she learned the skill from her sister. She sells her finished products to a middleman in the village who then takes them to sell in a Phnom Penh market.

Her husband has been working in a company for 6 months.

Sokneang is requesting her first loan of $350 to purchase silk materials for her silk weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her silk weaving business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional stock of cosmetics in bulk.

loans.name: Yan

texts.en:
Mr. Yan Y. and his wife, Mrs. Mot Prum, live in a small village outside of Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They married in 1979 and have three children: two sons who are married and live outside the family home, and one daughter who is attending school. 

Yan and his wife have been growing rice since they were married. In addition to farming he rents out his rice threshing machine to his neighbors. 
Yan is requesting his second loan of $150 US to purchase fuel oil for his rice threshing machine.

loans.use: To buy fuel oil for rice thresher

loans.name: Din

texts.en:
Selling groceries makes up a significant part of 28-year-old Din P.’s daily routine. Mrs. Din P. has been operating a grocery in front of her home for a year and is earning approximately $4 a day. Din P. owns a machine her husband uses to mill rice for a profit. This couple is married with a young child who is enrolled in school. 

Din P. faces difficulties traveling to buy her inventory from the market because she doesn’t own a vehicle. Due to that problem, she requests a loan to buy a used motorbike, which she will use as transportation. Din P. was not available that day so her husband is pictured instead.

loans.use: To buy a used motorbike to transport grocery inventory

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional stock of women's shoes in bulk

loans.name: Pativaine

texts.en:
Pativaine owns & operates a business venture, planting & harvesting taro for sale. She has 12 years of experience in this business. Pativaine needs a loan of WST $1500 to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome. She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 600 talas or US $250 per week) to improve the general living conditions of her family. In 2006, Pativaine joined SPBD to gain access to financial services. Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks, because they lack collateral. This is Pativaine's 4th loan with SPBD.

Overall Social Metric Score:* 1.6 out of 3 Level of Education: 1.5 out of 3 Level of total Household Income: 1.8 out of 3 Quality of Household Assets: 2.3 out of 3

*SPBD evaluates the living conditions of each of its borrowers. Generally, a loan manager evaluates a variety of social metrics on a scale out of 3 (the higher the number, the better off the person is) and these are averaged for the "overall social metric score." For example, a 3 out of 3 on "level of education" would mean that the borrower has graduated from university.

About SPBD

In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem. Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD.

loans.use: To purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome

loans.name: Poni

texts.en:
Poni F. is currently in the business of selling food in a restaurant and is requesting a loan to purchase crates of beer and sodas to sell. Poni is 24 years old and married to a doctor. She has one child who doesn't go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a retail shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Purchase crates of beer and sodas to sell

loans.name: Sokhann

texts.en:
Mr. Sokhann P., 45, and his wife, Mrs. Saroeun Sat, 40, (pictured here together) live along national road number one about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1989 and have four children: two sons and two daughters. Two of them assist their parents in the farming business while the other two attend school. 

Sokhann and his wife have been farming for 20 years. They grow many types of vegetables, such as cauliflower, cucumbers and other crops. In the future, the couple hopes to support their children in pursuing their education. 

Sokhann is requesting his first loan of $1,000 to pay for plowing and to buy fertilizer and pesticide to use on his farm.

loans.use: To pay for plowing fees and to buy fertilizer and pesticide to use on his farm

loans.name: Christopher

texts.en:
Christopher has a stall where he sells building materials at retail prices to his customers. He is a focused, hard worker. He is a LAPO client. LAPO, a Kiva partner, is committed to improving lives. 

He is 42 years old and married with four children. His wife sells sarongs to support the home. He hopes for a loan of 100,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more building materials to sell. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more building materials to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional stock of drinks in bulk

loans.name: Sitha

texts.en:
Mr. Sitha C., age 49, and his wife, Mrs. Sambok Se, 37, were married in 1992 and have four children: two sons and two daughters. All of them are in school. They live in a small village on National Road number 2, about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Sitha has been selling cows for more than 10 years. He buys cows from the nearby district and sells them to a middleman who comes to buy them at his house. His wife stays at home and does housework. 

Sitha is requesting his first loan of $150 to help purchase cows for resale.

loans.use: To buy cows for resale.

loans.name: Yim

texts.en:
Yim Y. has a piece of farmland behind her house that she inherited from her grandmother and on which she cultivates a variety of vegetables. She is 53 and is married to Thoeun Than, 48, who assists her with her crops. Yim Y. was busy working on her farm when the photo taken, so her husband is pictured instead. The family has four children: three are married and the other one is single, working in construction.

Currently, Yim Y. faces difficulty with transporting her vegetables to sell at the market because she has no vehicle to use. So she is requesting a loan of $500 which she will add to her saving in order to buy a motorcycle.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle to transport her vegetables to market

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients in bulk

loans.name: Michael

texts.en: Michael has a restaurant where he sells cooked foods and drinks. He loves cooking and that is why he commercialized his cooking skills. His clients love his cooked foods and the demand for them is high. Michael is 28 years old and is single without children. He is a LAPO client. He hopes for a loan of 100,000 NGN to purchase more drinks and foodstuffs to cook and sell. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders. About LAPO: Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) is committed to achieving the goal of economic empowerment of its clients through access to affordable financial services delivered in a cost-effective and innovative manner.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and foodstuffs to cook and sell

loans.name: Phoeun

texts.en:
Mr. Phoeun Y., 52, and his wife, Mrs. Sivorn Met, 33, (they are pictured together), live along National Road Number One about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 2004 and have no children yet. Mrs. Sivorn Met’s mother lives with them.

Phoeun and his wife have been farming for thirty years. They grow many kinds of vegetables such as cauliflowers, corn and cucumbers on their farmland in the village. The couple hopes to increase the volume of their products, so Phoeun is asking for his first loan of $1,000 to pay plowing fees and to buy fertilizer and pesticide to use on his farm.

loans.use: To pay plowing fees and to buy fertilizer and pesticide

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients in bulk

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria, 50 years old and married with five children, sells tubers of yam at retail prices to her customers. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers and hopes to be a yam distributor in the future. A client of LAPO, she hopes for a loan amount of 40,000 NGN to purchase more tubers of yam to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

About LAPO Lift Above Poverty Organization is committed to achieving the goal of economic empowerment of clients through access to affordable financial services delivered in a cost effective and innovative manner.

loans.use: To purchase more tubers of yam to sell

loans.name: Editha

texts.en: Editha V. is from the village of Rizal, Santiago City. She is 54 years old, is married and has three adult children. Editha owns and operates a business vending cosmetics products and accessories. She has been engaged in her business for over a year now. In 2009, Editha joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional items to sell. This loan will be her first from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional items to sell

loans.name: Kossiwavi Hanuvi

texts.fr: Cette dame vend depuis 1984 des produits de mercerie dans le quartier d’Attiégou à Lomé. Cette activité lui permet d’apporter sa contribution financière à son mari pour l’éducation scolaire de leurs 03 enfants. Elle dispose d’une boutique bien assez spacieuse dans laquelle tous ceux qui sont à la recherche de produits de mercerie trouvent leur compte. Elle a un besoin urgent en ce moment de disposer d’un nouveau stock ; c’est pour cette raison qu’elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 12 fermetures éclair, 20 foulards et bien d’autres articles indispensables.
texts.en:
This woman has been selling haberdashery products in the Attiégou area of Lomé since 1984. This business has allowed her to make a financial contribution to her husband for the schooling of their 3 children. She has a relatively spacious shop where everyone looking for haberdashery products can find what they want. At the moment she urgently needs new stock; it is for this reason that she is asking for a loan from WAGES to buy 12 zippers, 20 scarves as well as other essential items.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of scarves and zippers

loans.name: Penh

texts.en:
Mrs. Penh S. is 37 years old and her husband, Mr. Vanna Hul, is 39 years old. They live along National Road Number One about thirty-five kilometers from Phnom Penh. The couple were married in 1989 and have five children: two sons and three daughters, all of them in school.

Penh has been growing rice for twenty years, while her husband has been a security guard for one year. Penh doesn’t have enough capital to use for farming so she is requesting her first loan of $300 to purchase fertilizer, fuel oil and pesticides to use on her rice farm.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, oil and pesticides for her farm

loans.name: Awoyovi Mawunédi

texts.fr: Cette femme exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu la vente des produits d’alimentation générale. Elle a ouvert sa boutique depuis 2004 à Djagblé à Lomé. Cette activité joue un rôle très important dans sa vie et ceci lui permet d’aider financièrement son mari dans l’éducation de leurs 03 enfants. Elle vend de l’huile d’arachide, des tomates en boîtes, des pâtes alimentaires et même certains produits cosmétiques. Elle sollicite en ce moment un crédit de WAGES pour lui permettre d’acheter des céréales, des produits en plastique et certains ingrédients de cuisine.
texts.en:
This woman has a revenue-generating business selling grocery items.  She opened her store in 2004 in Djagblé in Lomé.  This business plays a very important role in her life, and it allows her to help her husband financially in educating their three children.  She sells peanut oil, canned tomatoes, pasta, and even cosmetics.  At this time, she's requesting a loan from WAGES enabling her to buy grains, plastic ware, and certain ingredients for cooking.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Grocery items to sell

loans.name: Yanjinlham

texts.en:
N. Yanjinlham lives with her husband and son in the Bayanzurkh district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her husband is retired and her son, age 28, drives a taxi. Yanjinlham operates a groceries and dairy trading business in the city with the help of her daughter-in-law. She also sells firewood from her home to supplement her income. Yanjinlham started her business in 2002 and has built a stable operation over the years. She is a very hardworking businesswoman and is focused on the future. Her business has provided her family with financial stablilty and has enabled her to improve her quality of life. Yanjinlham has many plans for the future and says, "With continued success, I hope to buy a house for my son." She is requesting a 1,190,000 tugrug loan to purchase more dairy products to sell in her business. Yanjinlham and her husband, Shagdarsuren, are shown in the photo. About XacBank: XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.
To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.
To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: To purchase more dairy products

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth has a stall where she sells cooking utensils at retail prices to her customers. She hopes to own a supermarket in the future. She is 40 years old and married with 6 children. Her husband is a commercial driver and he also supports the home. She is a LAPO client and hopes for a loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more cooking utensils to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders. About LAPO: Lift Above Poverty Organization is committed to achieving the goal of economic empowerment of their clients through access to affordable financial services delivered in a cost effective and innovative manner.

loans.use: To purchase more cooking utensils to sell
